description: TO PASS H.R. 11983, THE BILL AMENDING THE FEDERAL ELECTION CAMPAIGN ACT OF 1971 IN ORDER TO AUTHORIZE APPROPRIATIONS FOR THE OPERATION OF THE FEDERAL ELECTION COMMISSION IN FISCAL YEAR 1979.
Issue1: Campaign Contributions, Lobbying/House Ethics Campaign Laws

description: TO AMEND H.R. 13467 BY STRIKING THE $15 MILLION APPROPRIATION FOR THE INFLUENZA VACCINATION PROGRAM AND ADDING A $3 MILLION AUTHORIZATION FOR ADDITIONAL RESEARCH ON INFLUENZA VACCINATION PROGRAMS TO BE CONDUCTED BY THE NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES.
TO AMEND H.R. 13467 BY INCREASING THE APPROPRIATION FOR SCHOOL DISTRICTS THAT HAVE SUSTAINED DAMAGES IN EXCESS OF $200,000 AS THE RESULT OF A NATURAL DISASTER, TO APPROXIMATELY $15 MILLION.

THAT THE HOUSE RESOLVE ITSELF INTO THE COMMITTEE OF THE WHOLE FOR THE FURTHER CONSIDERATION OF H.R. 12433, THE BILL AMENDING AND EXTENDING CERTAIN FEDERAL LAWS RELATING TO HOUSING AND COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT PROGRAMS.

TO AMEND H.R. 12433 BY PROHIBITING THE USE OF THESE FUNDS FOR THE IMPLEMENTATION OF A REORGANIZATIONAL PLAN THAT WOULD SHIFT THE ADMINISTRATION OF MULTIFAMILY HOUSING PROGRAMS FROM LOCAL AREA OFFICES TO CENTRALIZED OFFICES.

TO AMEND H.R. 12433 BY STRIKING LANGUAGE THAT WOULD REQUIRE THE PROPERTY INSURANCE RATES FOR THE STATE-OPERATED F.A.I.R. (FAIR ACCESS TO INSURANCE REQUIREMENTS) PROGRAMS TO BE NO GREATER THAN THE RATES FOR PRIVATE PROPERTY INSURANCE AVAILABLE IN THE VOLUNTARY MARKET.

TO AMEND H.R. 12433 SO THAT THE RENT PAID BY SOCIAL SECURITY RECIPIENTS WHO RESIDE IN PUBLIC HOUSING CAN NOT BE INCREASED SOLELY AS A RESULT OF COST-OF-LIVING INCREASES OCCURING AFTER MAY 1978 IN THEIR SOCIAL SECURITY BENEFITS.

TO SUSPEND THE RULES AND PASS, AS AMENDED, H.R. 11823, THE BILL EXTENDING ELIGIBILITY FOR THE NATIONAL RESERVE'S RETIREMENT BENEFITS TO CERTAIN INDIVIDUALS WHO PARTICIPATED IN THE NATIONAL RESERVE OR THE NATIONAL GUARD PRIOR TO AUG. 16, 1945, BUT DID NOT SERVE ON ACTIVE DUTY DURING WORLD WAR I, WORLD WAR II OR THE KOREAN WAR.
TO SUSPEND THE RULES AND PASS, AS AMENDED, H.R. 12349, THE BILL DESIGNATING 34,500 ACRES OF THE DUNOIR BASIN IN THE SHOSHONE NATIONAL FOREST IN WYOMING AS AN ADDITION TO THE WASHAKIE WILDERNESS.

TO SUSPEND THE RULES AND PASS, AS AMENDED, H.R. 12973, THE BILL AMENDING TITLE XX OF THE SOCIAL SECURITY ACT SO AS TO INCREASE THE ENTITLEMENT CEILINGS FOR SOCIAL SERVICES PROGRAMS IN FISCAL YEARS 1979, 1980, AND 1981.
TO SUSPEND THE RULES AND PASS H.R. 11889, A BILL THAT INCREASES THE MONTHLY PENSION BENEFIT PAYABLE TO HOLDERS OF THE CONGRESSIONAL MEDAL OF HONOR FROM $100 TO $200.

TO SUSPEND THE RULES AND PASS, AS AMENDED, H.R. 11890, THE BILL PROVIDING FOR AN AUTOMATIC PRESUMPTION OF SERVICE-CONNECTED DEATH FOR VETERANS THAT WERE RATED TOTALLY AND PERMANENTLY SERVICE-CONNECTED DISABLED FOR A PERIOD OF LEAST TEN YEARS.  H.R. 11890 APPLIES THIS PRESUMPTION TO THE DETERMINATION OF ELIGIBILITY FOR DEPENDENCY AND INDEMNITY COMPENSATION.

TO AMEND H.R. 10285 BY ALLOWING THE STATES TO PASS AND ENFORCE STATE LAWS IDENTICAL TO THE FEDERAL LAWS CONTAINED IN THE COMMODITY EXCHANGE ACT SO THAT COMMODITY TRADE LAWS MAY BE ENFORCED THROUGH THE STATE COURT SYSTEMS AS WELL AS THROUGH THE FEDERAL COURT SYSTEM.
TO AMEND H.R. 10285 BY REQUIRING ANY PERSON WHO SELLS AN EXPORT COMMODITY TO REPORT IT TO THE COMMODITY FUTURES TRADING COMMISSION WITHIN 48 HOURS OF THE DATE OF THE SALE.

TO AGREE TO AN AMENDMENT OFFERED IN THE NATURE OF A SUBSTITUTE FOR THE UDALL AMENDMENT TO H.R. 3350, THE DEEP SEABED HARD MINERALS ACT.  THE BREAUX SUBSTITUTE AMENDMENT GIVES THE SECRETARY OF COMMERCE JURISDICTION OVER DEEP SEABED MINING OPERATIONS.  THE UDALL AMENDMENT GIVES THE SECRETARY OF THE INTERIOR JURISDICTION OVER THESE OPERATIONS.

TO AMEND H.R. 3350 SO AS TO DISPELL ANY INFERENCE THAT THE UNITED STATES IS CLAIMING JURISDICTION OVER ANY AREA OF THE OCEAN SEABED BEYOND THE 200 MILE LIMIT OF THE U.S.  THE MCCLOSKEY AMENDMENT STATES THAT ANY NATION OR INDIVIDUAL WHO HOLDS AN APPROVED COMPREHENSIVE WORK PLAN WILL HAVE THE RIGHT TO CONDUCT MINING OPERATIONS.

TO AMEND H.R. 7577, THE BILL AMENDING AND EXTENDING THE ECONOMIC OPPORTUNITY ACT OF 1964, BY RETAINING THE FUNDING FORMULA FOR COMMUNITY SERVICE AGENCIES THAT REQUIRES THE FEDERAL GOVERNMENT TO CONTRIBUTE 60% OF THE FUNDS AND THE STATE GOVERNMENT TO CONTRIBUTE 40%.

TO AGREE TO S. CON. RES. 98, A RESOLUTION PROVIDING THAT THE SENATE AND THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES SHALL NOT ADJOURN FOR MORE THAN THREE DAYS NOR ADJOURN SINE DIE UNTIL BOTH HOUSES OF CONGRESS HAVE ADOPTED A CONCURRENT RESOLUTION PROVIDING FOR ADJOURNMENT TO A DAY CERTAIN OR FOR ADJOURNMENT SINE DIE.

TO AMEND H.R. 12157, THE BILL AMENDING AND EXTENDING THE EXPORT-IMPORT BANK ACT FOR AN ADDITIONAL FIVE YEARS.  THE LONG (MD) AMENDMENT PROHIBITS THE EXPORT-IMPORT BANK FROM EXTENDING LOANS OR GUARANTEES FOR THE EXPANSION OF A COMMODITY UNTIL THE PRESIDENT CERTIFIES TO CONGRESS THAT THE COMMODITY IS NOT IN SURPLUS IN THE UNTITED STATES AND ITS IMPORTATION WOULD NOT THREATEN U.S. FIRMS MANUFACTURING A SIMILAR OR COMPETING PRODUCT.

TO AMEND H.R. 12157 BY PROHIBITING THE EXPORT-IMPORT BANK FROM EXTENDING LOANS OR GUARANTEES TO ANY COUNTRY WHOSE GOVERNMENT HAS ENGAGED IN A CONSISTENT PATTERN OF GROSS VIOLATIONS OF INTERNATIONALLY RECOGNIZED HUMAN RIGHTS.
TO AMEND H.R. 12157 BY PROHIBITING THE EXPORT-IMPORT BANK FROM PARTICIPATING IN ANY TRANSACTIONS WITH A COUNTRY THAT DOES NOT ENDORSE CERTAIN PRINCIPLES OF FAIR AND EQUAL EMPLOYMENT.

TO AMEND H.R. 12157 BY REQUIRING THE EXPORT-IMPORT BANK, IN THE EVENT OF A TRANSACTION INVOLVING THE SALE OF A NUCLEAR REACTOR, TO SUBMIT TO CONGRESS AN EVALUATION OF THE SAFETY STANDARDS AND NUCLEAR PRACTICES OF THE COUNTRIES PARTICIPATING IN THE TRANSACTIONS.
THAT THE HOUSE RESOLVE ITSELF INTO THE COMMITTEE OF THE WHOLE FOR THE FURTHER CONSIDERATION OF H.R. 9400, THE BILL PROTECTING THE RIGHTS OF INSTITUTIONALIZED PERSONS.
TO PASS H.R. 9400, THE BILL PROTECTING THE RIGHTS OF PERSONS LIVING IN STATE-RUN INSTITUTIONS FOR THE MENTALLY-IMPAIRED, IN JAILS, IN JUVENILE INSTITUTIONS, AND IN NURSING HOMES.
THAT THE HOUSE RESOLVE ITSELF INTO THE COMMITTEE OF THE WHOLE FOR THE CONSIDERATION OF H.R. 12432, THE BILL AUTHORIZING APPROPRIATIONS FOR THE COMMISSION ON CIVIL RIGHTS FOR AN ADDITIONAL FIVE YEARS.

TO AGREE TO SEVERAL AMENDMENTS TO H.R. 12432.  THE BUTLER AMENDMENTS STRIKE PROVISIONS IN THE BILL THAT WOULD AUTHORIZE THE COMMISSION ON CIVIL RIGHTS TO STUDY DISCRIMINATION BASED ON AGE OR HANDICAPS.
TO AMEND H.R. 12432 BY PROHIBITING MEMBERS OF THE COMMISSION OR ITS STAFF FROM LOBBYING FOR ANY LEGISLATION ON THE FEDERAL, STATE, OR LOCAL LEVEL.
Issue1: Campaign Contributions, Lobbying/House Ethics Campaign Laws

description: TO SUSPEND THE RULES AND PASS, AS AMENDED, H.R. 9998, THE BILL INCREASING THE AUTHORITY OF THE FEDERAL MARITIME COMMISSION TO REGULATE THE RATE-CUTTING PRACTICES OF CERTAIN FOREIGN-CONTROLLED OCEAN CARRIERS.

THAT THE HOUSE RESOLVE ITSELF INTO THE COMMITTEE OF THE WHOLE FOR THE CONSIDERATION OF H.R. 12514, THE BILL AUTHORIZING APPROPRIATIONS FOR INTERNATIONAL SECURITY ASSISTANCE PROGRAMS FOR FISCAL YEAR 1979.

TO SUSPEND THE RULES AND PASS, AS AMENDED, H.R. 12972, THE BILL INCREASING THE AMOUNT OF EARNINGS THAT DISABLED INDIVIDUALS CAN HAVE WITHOUT LOSING THEIR ELIGIBILITY FOR SOCIAL SECURITY INCOME PAYMENTS.

TO PASS H.R. 4030, THE BILL AMENDING THE INTERNAL REVENUE CODE OF 1954 SO AS TO ALLOW A CERTAIN PRIVATE FOUNDATION IN WAPAKONETA, OHIO TO HOLD 51% OF THE STOCK OF A LOCAL PUBLIC UTILITY WITHOUT BEING TAXED FOR EXCESS BUSINESS HOLDINGS.

TO MODIFY THE FASCELL AMENDMENT TO H.R. 12514, THE BILL AUTHORIZING APPROPRIATIONS FOR INTERNAITONAL SECURITY ASSISTANCE PROGRAMS FOR FISCAL YEAR 1979.  THE MODIFIED FASCELL AMENDMENT WILL LIFT THE U.S. ARMS EMBARGO AGAINST TURKEY UPON THE PRESIDENT'S CERTIFICATION TO CONGRESS THAT IT IS IN THE INTEREST OF THE U.S. AND N.A.T.O. TO DO SO, AND THAT "TURKEY IS ACTING IN GOOD FAITH TO ACHIEVE A JUST AND PEACEFUL SETTLEMENT OF THE CYPRUS PROBLEM."  THE ORIGINAL FASCELL AMENDMENT WOULD HAVE LIFTED THE ARMS EMBARGO FOR A PERIOD OF ONE YEAR AS SOON AS TURKEY REMOVED ITS TROOPS FROM FAMAGUSTA, AND AS SOON AS THE UNITED NATIONS TOOK OVER THE ADMINISTRATION OF SAID CITY, AND TALKS AIMED AT SETTLEMENT OF THE CYPRUS PROBLEM WERE RESUMED.

TO AGREE TO AN AMENDMENT OFFERED IN THE NATURE OF A SUBSTITUTE FOR THE STRATTON AMENDMENT TO H.R. 12514.  THE MODIFIED STRATTON AMENDMENT EXPRESSES THE SENSE OF CONGRESS THAT FURTHER WITHDRAWAL OF U.S. TROOPS FROM SOUTH KOREA "MAY SERIOUSLY RISK UPSETTING THE MILITARY BALANCE IN THAT REGION AND REQUIRES FULL ADVANCE CONSULTATION WITH THE CONGRESS."  THE ORIGINAL STRATTON AMENDMENT WOULD HAVE DRASTICALLY REDUCED THE AUTHORIZATION FOR THE TRANSFER OF U.S. MILITARY EQUIPMENT TO SOUTH KOREA, A TRANSFER WITHOUT REIMBURSEMENT THAT WAS CONNECTED TO THE WITHDRAWAL OF NOT MORE THAN 6,000 U.S. TROOPS.

TO MODIFY THE ZABLOCKI AMENDMENT OFFERED IN THE NATURE OF A SUBSTITUTE FOR THE BAUMAN AMENDMENT TO H.R. 12514.  THE FINDLEY MODIFYING AMENDMENT IMMEDIATELY LIFTS U.S. ECONOMIC SANCTIONS AGAINST RHODESIA UNLESS THE PRESIDENT DETERMINES THAT THE GOVERNMENT OF RHODESIA HAS "REFUSED" TO PARTICIPATE AND NEGOTIATE IN GOOD FAITH AT AN ALL-PARTIES CONFERENCE TO DISCUSS RELEVENT ISSUES, OR IF THE PRESIDENT DETERMINES THAT THE RHODESIAN GOVERNMENT "FAILED TO SCHEDULE" FREE ELECTIONS.  THE ZABLOCKI SUBSTITUTE AMENDMENT LIFTS U.S. SANCTIONS AGAINST RHODESIA AS SOON AS THE PRESIDENT DETERMINES THAT THE SOUTH RHODESIAN GOVERNMENT HAS COMMITTED ITSELF TO PARTICIPATE IN AND NEGOTIATE IN GOOD FAITH IN AN ALL-PARTIES CONFERENCE, AND AS SOON AS A NEW RHODESIAN GOVERNMENT, CHOSEN BY FREE ELECTION, HAS BEEN INSTALLED.  THE ORIGINAL BAUMAN AMENDMENT BANS U.S. ECONOMIC SANCTIONS AGAINST RHODESIA BEFORE OCT. 1, 1979 UNLESS THE RHODESIAN GOVERNMENT "HAS NOT COMMITTED ITSELF" TO AN ALL-PARTIES CONFERENCE OR HAS "MADE NO DEFINITE PLANS" FOR FREE ELECTIONS.

TO MODIFY THE ZABLOCKI SUBSTITUTE AMENDMENT FOR THE BAUMAN AMENDMENT (SEE RC 634) TO H.R. 12514.  THE ICHORD MODIFYING AMENDMENT BANS U.S. SANCTIONS AGAINST RHODESIA AFTER DEC. 31, 1978 UNLESS THE PRESIDENT DETERMINES THAT A NEW RHODESIAN GOVERNMENT HAS NOT BEEN INSTALLED NOR ELECTED BY FREE ELECTIONS IN WHICH ALL POLITICAL GROUPS HAVE BEEN FREE TO PARTICIPATE.

TO AMEND H.R. 12514 BY PROHIBITING THE DELIVERY OF WEAPONS OR SERVICES THAT WERE SOLD TO CHILE BEFORE ENACTMENT OF THIS BILL UNTIL SUCH TIME AS THE CHILEAN GOVERNMENT TURNS OVER TO THE U.S. THOSE CHILEANS INDICTED FOR THE MURDER OF ORLANDO LETELIER AND RONNI MOFFITT.

TO AMEND H.R. 12931, THE BILL MAKING APPROPRIATIONS FOR FOREIGN ASSISTANCE AND RELATED PROGRAMS FOR FISCAL YEAR 1979.  THE YOUNG (FL) AMENDMENT STRIKES THE $49 MILLION APPROPRIATION EARMAKRED FOR THE PURCHASE OF INDIAN RUPEES TO BE USED IN INDIA.

TO MODIFY THE YOUNG (FL) AMENDMENT (SEE RC 645) TO H.R. 12931.  THE MODIFYING HARKIN AMENDMENT WOULD PROHIBIT USE OF THESE FUNDS FOR INDIRECT AID TO CHILE, ARGENTINA, URUGUAY, KOREA, NICARAGUA, INDONESIA AND THE PHILIPPINES.
TO AMEND H.R. 12931 BY PROHIBITING USE OF THESE FUNDS FOR DIRECT OR INDIRECT AID TO VIETNAM, CAMBODIA, LAOS, AND UGANDA.

TO AMEND H.R. 12931 BY REDUCING THE APPROPRIATION FOR FOREIGN MILITARY CREDIT SALES BY $12.6 MILLION AND BY REQUIRING THAT NOT MORE THAN $2.5 MILLION OF SAID APPROPRIATION BE MADE AVAILABLE TO LEBANON, AND NOT MORE THAN $8.5 MILLION BE MADE AVAILABLE TO JORDAN.
TO AMEND H.R. 13635 BY INCREASING THE APPROPRIATIONS FOR THE INCENTIVE PROGRAMS FOR THE DIFFERENT BRANCHES OF THE RESERVE AND OF THE NATIONAL GUARD.

TO AMEND H.R. 13635 BY STRIKING THE $3 MILLION APPROPRIATION FOR THE DEVELOPMENT OF THE AVCR-1360 DIESEL ENGINE FOR USE IN FUTURE ARMY AND/OR MARINE CORPS COMBAT VEHICLES.  THE GIAIMO AMENDMENT ALSO INCREASES THE APPROPRIATION FOR THE ARMY'S FOOD RESEARCH PROGRAMS BY $1 MILLION.

TO AMEND H.R. 13635 BY PROHIBITING USE OF THESE FUNDS FOR PROCUREMENT OF TACTICAL SUPPORT OR OF TRACKED OR NON-TRACKED VEHICLES MANUFACTURED OUTSIDE OF THE UNITED STATES, EXCEPT FOR TEST AND EVALUATION PURPOSES.

TO OFFER AN AMENDMENT IN THE NATURE OF A SUBSTITUTE FOR THE HARKIN AMENDMENT (SEE RC 662) TO H.R. 13635.  THE MITCHELL (MD) SUBSTITUTE AMENDMENT WOULD REDUCE ALL APPROPRIATIONS NOT REQUIRED BY LAW BY 1%.
TO AMEND H.R. 13635 BY PROHIBITING USE OF THESE FUNDS TO PAY FOR ABORTIONS EXCEPT WHEN THE LIFE OF THE MOTHER WOULD BE ENDANGERED IF THE FETUS WERE CARRIED TO TERM.
TO AGREE TO THE CONFERENCE REPORT ON H.R. 2777, THE BILL PROVIDING FOR THE DEVELOPMENT OF SPECIALIZED CREDIT SOURCES FOR CONSUMER COOPERATIVES.
TO AGREE TO H. RES. 1201, A RESOLUTION STATING THAT THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES DOES NOT FAVOR THE PRESIDENT'S CIVIL SERVICE REORGANIZATION PLAN.

TO MODIFY THE ERLENBORN AMENDMENT (SEE RC 673) TO H.R. 12452.  THE GOODLING AMENDMENT MAKES THE PAYMENT OF UNEMPLOYMENT INSURANCE BENEFITS BY PRIME SPONSORS FOR PERSONS IN PUBLIC SERVICE JOBS OPTIONAL RATHER THAN MANDATORY.

TO AMEND THE KREBS AMENDMENT OFFERED IN THE NATURE OF A SUBSTITUTE FOR THE ERLENBORN AMENDMENT (SEE RC 673) TO H.R. 12452.  THE ASHBROOK AMENDMENT STRIKES THE PROVISION THAT ALLOWS USE OF CETA FUNDS FOR RETIREMENT SYSTEM CONTRIBUTIONS IF THE CETA EMPLOYEE IS LIKELY TO BENEFIT FROM THE PENSION PLAN IN THE FUTURE.  THE KREBS SUBSTITUTE AMENDMENT PROHIBITS USE OF CETA FUNDS FOR RETIREMENT SYSTEM CONTRIBUTIONS EXCEPT WHEN THE CETA WORKER IS LIKELY TO FROM THE PENSION PLAN IN THE FUTURE.

TO AMEND H.R. 12452 BY LIMITING CETA SALARIES TO $12,000 FOR JOBS IN HIGH WAGE AREAS AND $10,000 FOR JOBS IN LOW WAGE AREAS, AND BY SETTING THE AVERAGE CETA WAGE AT $7,000, TO BE ADJUSTED ANNUALLY BY A PERCENTAGE NO GREATER THAN THE PERCENTAGE CHANGE IN THE CONSUMER PRICE INDEX.

TO AMEND H.R. 12452 BY PUTTING A $3.2 BILLION CEILING ON PUBLIC SERVICE EMPLOYMENT SPENDING EXCEPT DURING PERIODS OF CRITICALLY HIGH UNEMPLOYMENT.  THE JEFFORDS AMENDMENT ALSO SHIFTS AUTHORIZATIONS FROM PUBLIC SERVICE FUNDS TO YOUTH PROGRAMS AND PROGRAMS IN THE PRIVATE SECTOR FOR THE ECONOMICALLY DISADVANTAGED.

TO AGREE TO SEVERAL COMMITTEE AMENDMENTS TO H.R. 13511 THAT PROVIDE FOR AN OVERALL $16.3 BILLION TAX CUT, RATE CUTS FOR INDIVIDUALS IN CERTAIN TAX BRACKETS, A 6% WIDENING OF EXISTING BRACKETS, AND AN INCREASE IN BOTH THE STANDARD DEDUCTION AND THE PERSONAL EXEMPTION.  THESE COMMITTEE AMENDMENTS WOULD ALSO FIX THE INVESTMENT TAX CREDIT PERMANENTLY AT 10%, RESTRUCTURE CAPITAL GAINS TAXES (EXEMPTING UP TO $100,000 IN PROFITS FROM THE SALE OF RESIDENCES ONCE IN A TAXPAYER'S LIFETIME), AND WOULD REDUCE TAXES FOR SMALL BUSINESSES.
TO AGREE TO A COMMITTEE AMENDMENT TO H.R. 13511 THAT WOULD ALLOW AN INFLATION ADJUSTMENT TO BE MADE ON THE SALE OF CERTAIN CAPITAL ASSETS, INCLUDING STOCK AND REAL ESTATE.

TO AGREE TO AN AMENDMENT OFFERED IN THE NATURE OF A SUBSTITUTE FOR H.R. 13511.  THE VANIK SUBSTITUTE AMENDMENT EXTENDS THE FOUR TAX CUTS DUE TO EXPIRE AT THE END OF 1978, AND INCLUDES THE EARNED INCOME CREDIT AND THE TARGETED JOBS CREDIT PROVISIONS AS THEY APPEARED IN THE VERSION OF H.R. 13511 REPORTED BY THE COMMITTEE ON WAYS AND MEANS.

TO AMEND H.R. 13511 BY REDISTRIBUTING THE INDIVIDUAL TAX CUTS SO AS TO BENEFIT THOSE PERSONS EARNING LESS THAN $50,000 ANNUALLY.  THE CORMAN AMENDMENT ALSO INCREASES THE TOTAL AMOUNT OF THE INCOME TAX CUT BY APPROXIMATELY $2 BILLION.

TO RECOMMIT H.R. 13511 TO THE WAYS AND MEANS COMMITTEE WITH INSTRUCTIONS TO REPORT IT BACK WITH AN AMENDMENT THAT WOULD PROVIDE FOR AN ACROSS-THE-BOARD CUT IN INDIVIDUAL INCOME TAXES OF APPROXIMATELY 33% TO BE PHASED IN OVER THE NEXT THREE YEARS.

TO PASS H.R. 13007, THE BILL AMENDING THE CONSUMER CREDIT PROTECTION ACT SO AS TO ESTABLISH THE RIGHTS, REMEDIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES OF ALL PARTICIPANTS IN THE UTILIZATION OF ELECTRONIC FUND TRANSFER SERVICES.

TO MODIFY THE LONG (MD) AMENDMENT TO H.R. 12931, THE BILL MAKING FOREIGN AID APPROPRIATIONS FOR FISCAL YEAR 1979.  THE ORIGINAL LONG AMENDMENT WOULD HAVE REDUCED THE FUNDS FOR THE INTER-AMERICAN DEVELOPMENT BANK AND THE INTERNATIONAL DEVELOPMENT ASSOCIATION BY $548 MILLION. THE OBEY AMENDMENT REDUCES THESE FUNDS BY APPROXIMATELY $24 MILLION.
TO AMEND H.R. 12931 BY PROHIBITING THAT THE U.S. FUNDS APPROPRIATED TO THE INTERNATIONAL DEVELOPMENT ASSOCIATION BE USED TO FINANCE ANY ASSISTANCE OR REPARATIONS TO VIETNAM.

TO AMEND H.R. 12931 BY PROHIBITING THAT THE FUNDS APPROPRIATED TO THE INTERNATIONAL FINANCIAL INSTITUTIONS BE USED TO ESTABLISH OR EXPAND PRODUCTION FOR EXPORTS OF STEEL, GRAINS, SUGAR, PALM OIL, CITRUS CROPS, TOBACCO OR TIRES.

TO MODIFY THE YOUNG (FL) AMENDMENT TO H.R. 12931.  THE YOUNG AMENDMENT PROVIDES FOR A 2% CUT IN ALL ITEMS IN THE BILL, EXCEPT THE FUNDS FOR ISRAEL AND EGYPT.  THE MILLER MODIFYING AMENDMENT INCREASES THE REDUCTION FROM 2% TO 8%.

TO AGREE TO AN AMENDMENT OFFERED IN THE NATURE OF A SUBSTITUTE FOR THE YOUNG (FL) AMENDMENT (SEE RC 697) TO H.R. 12931.  THE HARKIN SUBSTITUTE AMENDMENT PROVIDES FOR A 2% REDUCTION IN ALL ITEMS NOT PREVIOUSLY REDUCED BY FLOOR AMENDMENTS, INCLUDING THE FUNDS FOR ISRAEL AND EGYPT.
TO ORDER THE PREVIOUS QUESTION ON H. RES. 1295, THE RULE TO CONSIDER H. J. RES. 638, THE RESOLUTION EXTENDING THE DEADLINE FOR THE RATIFICATION OF THE EQUAL RIGHTS AMENDMENT.
TO AMEND H. J. RES. 638 BY ALLOWING STATES WHICH RATIFIED THE AMENDMENT DURING THE SEVEN-YEAR PERIOD TO RESCIND RATIFICATION DURING THE EXTENSION PERIOD.

TO MODIFY THE GIAIMO AMENDMENT OFFERED IN THE NATURE OF A SUBSTITUTE FOR H. CON. RES. 683, THE SECOND CONCURRENT RESOLUTION ON THE FEDERAL BUDGET FOR FISCAL YEAR 1979. THE GIAIMO SUBSTITUTE (OFFERED BY MR. GIAMO FOR THE BUDGET COMMITTEE) BRINGS THE BUDGET RESOLUTION IN CONFORMITY WITH RECENT ACTIONS TAKEN BY THE HOUSE, AND SETS TARGETS FOR REVENUES AT $450 BILLION, BUDGET AUTHORITY AT $561 BILLION, AND OUTLAYS AT $489.9 BILLION, WITH A DEFICIT OF $39.8 BILLION AND A PUBLIC DEBT OF $838.1 BILLION.  THE HOLT AMENDMENT REDUCES THE EDUCATION, TRAINING, EMPLOYMENT AND SOCIAL SERVICES FUNCTION BY $135 MILLION IN BUDGET AUTHORITY AND $355 MILLION IN OUTLAYS, AND ALSO REDUCES THE GENERAL PURPOSE FISCAL ASSISTANCE FUNCTION BY $88 MILLION IN BUDGET AUTHORITY AND $338 MILLION IN OUTLAYS.

TO MODIFY THE GIAIMO SUBSTITUTE AMENDMENT (SEE RC 707) FOR H. CON. RES. 683.  THE MATTOX AMENDMENT WOULD REDUCE BUDGET AUTHORITY AND OUTLAYS TO REFLECT SENATE COMMITTEE CUTS IN ANTI-RECESSION AID TO STATES AND CITIES AND HOUSE CUTS IN CETA FUNDING.

TO AMEND THE GIAIMO SUBSTITUTE AMENDMENT (SEE RC 707) FOR H. CON. RES. 683.  THE LATTA AMENDMENT REDUCES THE TOTAL BUDGET AUTHORITY BY $22.5 BILLION, AND THE TOTAL OUTLAYS, THE DEFICIT, AND THE TOTAL DEBT BY $10.5 BILLION, AND DIRECTS THE APPROPRIATIONS COMMITTEES TO REPORT LEGISLATION DECREASING BUDGET AUTHORITY BY THE REQUIRED $22.5 BILLION.

TO MODIFY THE GIAIMO SUBSTITUTE (SEE RC 707) FOR H. CON. RES. 683 BY REDUCING THE TOTAL BUDGET AUTHORITY AND TOTAL OUTLAYS BY $753 MILLION, THEREBY ELIMINATING FUNDS FOR PROPOSED COUNTERCYCLICAL PROGRAMS.

TO RECEDE FROM DISAGREEMENT AND CONCUR IN SENATE AMENDMENT #48 TO H.R. 13467, THE BILL MAKING SUPPLEMENTAL APPROPRIATIONS FOR FISCAL YEAR 1978.  AMENDMENT #48 APPROPRIATES APPROXIMATELY $54.8 MILLION FOR CONSTRUCTION OF THE NEW HART SENATE OFFICE BUILDING.

TO AGREE TO THE CONFERENCE REPORT ON H.R. 12240, THE BILL AUTHORIZING APPROPRIATIONS FOR FISCAL YEAR 1979 FOR INTELLIGENCE AND INTELLIGENCE-RELATED ACTIVITIES OF THE U.S. GOVERNMENT, THE INTELLIGENCE COMMUNITY STAFF AND THE C.I.A. RETIREMENT AND DISABILITY SYSTEM.

TO AMEND H.R. 12432, THE BILL AUTHORIZING APPROPRIATIONS FOR THE COMMISSION ON CIVIL RIGHTS FOR AN ADDITIONAL FIVE YEARS, BY PROHIBITING THE COMMISSION FROM STUDYING AND APPRAISING ABORTION POLICIES AND ABORTION LAWS OF THE FEDERAL GOVERNMENT OR OF ANY OTHER GOVERNMENTAL AUTHORITY.

TO AMEND H.R. 7308, THE FOREIGN INTELLIGENCE SURVEILLANCE ACT OF 1978, BY ALLOWING ELECTRONIC SURVEILLANCE OF FOREIGN PERSONS WITHOUT A WARRANT, AS LONG AS A SURVEILLANCE CERTIFICATE HAS BEEN ISSUED BY THE ATTORNEY GENERAL AND A DESIGNATED EXECUTIVE BRANCH PRESIDENTIAL APPOINTEE WHOSE APPOINTMENT HAS BEEN CONFIRMED BY THE SENATE.
TO PASS H.R. 10929, THE BILL AUTHORIZING APPROPRIATIONS TO THE DEPARTMENT OF DEFENSE FOR WEAPONS PROCUREMENT FOR FISCAL YEAR 1979, THUS OVERRIDING THE PRESIDENT'S AUG. 17 VETO OF THE BILL.

TO INSTRUCT THE HOUSE CONFEREES ON H.R. 12930, THE BILL MAKING APPROPRIATIONS FOR THE TREASURY DEPARTMENT, THE U.S. POSTAL SERVICE AND THE EXECUTIVE OFFICE OF THE PRESIDENT FOR FISCAL YEAR 1979, TO AGREE TO SENATE AMENDMENT #7 TO THE BILL.  AMENDMENT #7 PROHIBITS THE IMPOSITION OF OIL IMPORT FEES.

TO AMEND H.R. 7308, THE FOREIGN INTELLIGENCE SURVEILLANCE ACT OF 1978, BY REQUIRING THE PRESIDENT TO NOTIFY THE HOUSE AND SENATE INTELLIGENCE COMMITTEES WHEN HE HAS REASON TO BELIEVE THAT THE COMMUNICATIONS OF U.S. CITIZENS ARE BEING MONITORED BY FOREIGN AGENTS OR FOREIGN GOVERNMENTS.  THE KEMP AMENDMENT ALSO REQUIRES THE PRESIDENT TO NOTIFY THE TARGETS OF SURVEILLANCE AND TO ASK THE FOREIGN POWER INVOLVED TO CEASE AND DESIST SUCH SURVEILLANCE, AS LONG AS SUCH ACTION WOULD NOT SERIOUSLY THREATEN THE NATIONAL SERCURITY OF THE UNITED STATES.

TO AGREE TO AN AMENDMENT OFFERED IN THE NATURE OF A SUBSTITUTE FOR H.R. 7308.  THE MCCLORY SUBSTITUTE WOULD STRIKE THE REQUIREMENT FOR OBTAINING A WARRANT FOR ELECTRONIC SURVEILLANCE, STRIKE THE CRIMINAL STANDARD FOR SURVEILLANCE OF U.S. CITIZENS, AND ALLOW SURVEILLANCE OF U.S. PERSONS AS LONG AS IT HAD BEEN APPROVED BY THE PRESIDENT, THE ATTORNEY GENERAL AND AN EXECUTIVE BRANCH OFFICIAL WHOSE APPOINTMENT HAD BEEN CONFIRMED BY THE SENATE.

TO AMEND H.R. 7308 BY ALLOWING WARRANTLESS SURVEILLANCE OF FOREIGN PERSONS, PROVIDED THAT A SURVEILLANCE CERTIFICATE HAS BEEN ISSUED BY THE ATTORNEY GENERAL AND A DESIGNATED EXECUTIVE BRANCH PRESIDENTIAL APPOINTEE WHOSE APPOINTMENT HAS BEEN CONFIRMED BY THE SENATE.  THIS AMENDMENT WAS PREVIOUSLY AGREED TO IN THE COMMITTEE OF THE WHOLE ON SEPT. 6, 1978 (SEE RC 727).
TO RECOMMIT H.R. 7308 TO THE SELECT COMMITTEE ON INTELLIGENCE WITH INSTRUCTIONS TO REPORT IT BACK FORTHWITH WITH AN AMENDMENT ALLOWING WARRANTLESS SURVEILLANCE OF OFFICIAL FOREIGN POWERS.

TO AGREE TO A COMMITTEE AMENDMENT TO H.R. 11711 THAT WOULD EXTEND COVERAGE TO WORKERS THAT HAVE AT LEAST 40 WEEKS OF EMPLOYMENT IN THE 104 WEEKS IMMEDIATELY PRECEDING THEIR LAYOFF, AS WELL AS WORKERS THAT HAVE AT LEAST 26 WEEKS OF EMPLOYMENT IN THE 52 WEEKS PRECEDING THEIR LAYOFF. H.R. 11711 IS THE BILL IMPROVING THE OPERATION OF THE ADJUSTMENT ASSISTANCE PROGRAMS FOR WORKERS AND FIRMS HURT BY IMPORT COMPETITION.
TO AMEND H.R. 11280 BY EXTENDING THE USE OF VETERANS' PREFERENCE (FOR VIETNAM-ERA VETERANS WHO SERVED IN THE VIETNAM THEATER) FOR FIFTEEN YEARS OR UNTIL DEC. 31, 1985, WHICHEVER CAME LATER.
TO AGREE TO SEVERAL AMENDMENTS TO H.R. 11280, THE EFFECT OF WHICH WOULD BE TO RETAIN EXISTING VETERANS' PREFERENCE STANDARDS.
TO AMEND H.R. 11280 BY ALLOWING THE FBI TO HAVE AT LEAST 140 EMPLOYEES IN THE GS16-18 RANGE, DESPITE OTHER PROVISIONS THAT LIMIT THE NUMBER OF EXECUTIVE-LEVEL POSITIONS IN FEDERAL AGENCIES.
TO AMEND H.R. 11280 BY STRIKING THE LABOR-MANAGEMENT AND EMPLOYEE RELATIONS PROVISIONS FROM THE BILL.
TO SUSPEND THE RULES AND PASS, AS AMENDED, H.R. 12860, THE BILL SETTLING CLAIMS OF THE NARRAGANSETT INDIANS TO LANDS IN THE TOWN OF CHARLESTOWN, RHODE ISLAND.

TO SUSPEND THE RULES AND PASS, AS AMENDED, H.R. 13311, THE BILL AMENDING THE PORTS AND WATERWAYS SAFETY ACT OF 1972 SO AS TO PROVIDE FOR GREATER SUPERVISION AND CONTROL OF FOREIGN AND DOMESTIC VESSELS OPERATING ON U.S. WATERWAYS AND PORTS.
TO SUSPEND THE RULES AND PASS, AS AMENDED, H.R. 12026, THE BILL CREATING THE INDIAN PEAKS WILDERNESS AREA AND THE ARAPAHO NATIONAL RECREATION AREA IN COLORADO.

TO SUSPEND THE RULES AND AGREE TO H. RES. 1342, A RESOLUTION STATING THAT THE HOUSE WILL CONCUR, WITH AMENDMENTS, IN TWO SENATE AMENDMENTS TO H.R. 1337, THE BILL AMENDING THE INTERNAL REVENUE CODE OF 1954 WITH RESPECT TO THE EXCISE TAX ON CERTAIN TRUCKS, BUSES, TRACTORS, ETC.
TO SUSPEND THE RULES AND PASS, AS AMENDED, H.R. 13331, THE BILL DESIGNATING SEVERAL NEW LOCATIONS FOR FEDERAL DISTRICT COURTS AND REALINING THE DISTRICT COURT DIVIDING LINES IN SEVERAL STATES.

TO MODIFY THE UDALL SUBSTITUTE AMENDMENT FOR THE COLLINS AMENDMENT TO H.R. 11280.  THE ERLENBORN AMENDMENT PROHIBITS EMPLOYEES OF THE FEDERAL ELECTION COMMISSION FROM BEING REPRESENTED BY A UNION THAT MAINTAINS A POLITICAL ACTION COMMITTEE OR THAT ADVOCATES ELECTION OR DEFEAT OF ANY CANDIDATE FOR FEDERAL OFFICE.  THE UDALL SUBSTITUTE AMENDMENT COMPROMISES THE BILL'S LANGUAGE AND THE ADMINISTRATION'S PROPOSALS FOR THE LABOR MANAGEMENT PROVISIONS OF THE BILL.  THE COLLINS AMENDMENT EMBODIES THE ADMINISTRATION'S PROPOSALS AND GIVES BASIC COLLECTIVE BARGAINING RIGHTS TO FEDERAL EMPLOYEES ON ISSUES OF PERSONNEL POLICIES AND WORKING CONDITIONS.

TO AGREE TO AN AMENDMENT, AS MODIFIED BY THE UDALL SUBSTITUTE, TO H.R. 11280.  THE MODIFIED COLLINS AMENDMENT COMPROMISES COMMITTEE LANGUAGE AND THE ADMINISTRATION'S PROPOSALS FOR THE LABOR-MANAGEMENT PROVISIONS OF THE BILL. (SEE RC 763)
TO AMEND H.R. 11280 BY LIMITING THE PERMISSABLE OUTSIDE EARNED INCOME OF FEDERAL EMPLOYEES IN PAY GRADES GS-13 OR ABOVE TO NO MORE THAN 15% OF THEIR FEDERAL SALARIES.

TO AGREE TO SEVERAL AMENDMENTS TO H.R. 11280 THAT WOULD HAVE THE EFFECT OF RETAINING EXISTING VETERANS' PREFERENCE STANDARDS.  (THESE AMENDMENTS WERE PREVIOUSLY ADOPTED IN THE COMMITTEE OF THE WHOLE ON SEPT. 11, 1978.  SEE RC 747.)
TO AMEND H.R. 8729 BY REQUIRING AIRPORTS WHOSE AIRCRAFT NOISE AFFECTS POPULATIONS LIVING IN ADJACENT STATES, TO COMPLY WITH THIS BILL'S REQUIREMENTS FOR NOISE CONTROL PROGRAMS.
TO AMEND H.R. 8729 BY AUTHORIZING AN ADDITIONAL $25 MILLION IN 1979 AND IN 1980, TO BE DIVIDED EQUALLY AMONG THE FIFTY STATES AND USED FOR THE DEVELOPMENT OF GENERAL AVIATION AIRPORTS.

TO AGREE TO A MODIFIED AMENDMENT TO H.R. 8729 THAT WOULD STRIKE TITLE III OF THE BILL AND SUBSTITUTE IN LIEU THEREOF THE TEXT OF H.R. 11986, THE BILL ON CHANGES IN AIR TRANSPORTATION TAXES AS REPORTED BY THE COMMITTEE ON WAYS AND MEANS.

TO RECOMMIT H.R. 8729 TO THE COMMITTEE ON PUBLIC WORKS AND TRANSPORTATION WITH INSTRUCTIONS TO REPORT IT BACK FORTHWITH WITH AN AMENDMENT STRIKING TITLE III OF THE BILL AND INSERTING LANGUAGE PROVIDING FOR A 2% REDUCTION IN THE 8% AIRLINE PASSENGER TICKET TAX AND A 2% REDUCTION IN THE EXISTING 5% AIR CARGO TAX.

TO INSTRUCT THE HOUSE CONFEREES ON H.R. 9214 TO AGREE TO THE SENATE AMENDMENTS TO SECTIONS 4 AND 7 OF THE BILL.  H.R. 9214 IS THE BILL AMENDING THE BRETTON WOODS AGREEMENTS ACT TO AUTHORIZE U.S. PARTICIPATION IN THE SUPPLEMENTARY FINANCING FACILITY OF THE INTERNATIONAL MONETARY FUND (IMF). THE SENATE AMENDMENTS IN QUESTION WOULD INSTRUCT THE U.S. EXECUTIVE DIRECTOR TO IMF TO OPPOSE ANY IMF LOANS TO NATIONS PROVIDING AID OR ASSISTANCE TO TERRORISTS, AND WOULD MANDATE A BALANCED FEDERAL BUDGET BEGINNING IN FISCAL YEAR 1981.

TO AGREE TO H. RES. 1242, A RESOLUTION STATING THAT THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES DISAPPROVES OF REORGANIZATION PLAN NO. 3, AS SUBMITTED BY THE PRESIDENT ON JUNE 19, 1978. REORGANIZATION PLAN NO. 3 PROVIDES FOR THE ESTABLISHMENT OF A FEDERAL EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT AGENCY TO MANAGE A NUMBER OF CIVIL PREPAREDNESS AND DISASTER RELIEF FUNCTIONS PRESENTLY SCATTERED IN VARIOUS FEDERAL AGENCIES AND DEPARTMENTS.
TO AGREE TO THE CONFERENCE REPORT ON S. 2701, THE BILL REESTABLISHING THE WATER RESOURCES COUNCIL AND AUTHORIZING APPROPRIATIONS FOR THE COUNCIL FOR FISCAL YEAR 1979.

TO AGREE TO H. RES. 1350, THE RESOLUTION AUTHORIZING THE SPEAKER OF THE HOUSE TO CERTIFY THE REPORT OF THE COMMITTEE ON STANDARDS OF OFFICIAL CONDUCT WITH RESPECT TO THE PROCEEDINGS AGAINST HANCHO C. KIM.  THIS RESOLUTION ALSO AUTHORIZES THE SPEAKER TO RECOMMEND TO THE U.S. ATTORNEY FOR THE DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA THAT MR. KIM BE PROSECUTED FOR CRIMINAL CONTEMPT OF CONGRESS.

TO SUSPEND THE RULES AND PASS, AS AMENDED, H.R. 13817, THE BILL AMENDING THE SOCIAL SECURITY ACT SO AS TO PROVIDE FOR THE PARTICIPATION OF NONPHYSICIAN HEALTH PROFESSIONALS IN THE ACTIVITIES OF THE PROFESSIONAL STANDARDS REVIEW ORGANIZATIONS THAT REVIEW THE QUALITY OF FEDERAL HEALTH SERVICES.

TO SUSPEND THE RULES AND CONCUR IN THE SENATE AMENDMENTS TO H.R. 7819, THE BILL REPEALING A 1790 LAW GRANTING FULL CIVIL AND CRIMINAL IMMUNITY TO THE ENTIRE FOREIGN DIPLOMATIC COMMUNITY LIVING IN THE U.S.A.  THE SENATE AMENDMENTS IN QUESTION WILL ALLOW U.S. CITIZENS TO TAKE DIRECT ACTIONS AGAINST THE INSURANCE COMPANIES HOLDING THE LIABILITY POLICIES OF FOREIGN DIPLOMATS.

TO SUSPEND THE RULES AND PASS, AS AMENDED, H.R. 12460, THE BILL EXTENDING FUNDING FOR THE MIGRANT HEALTH PROGRAM, THE COMMUNITY HEALTH CENTERS PROGRAM AND THE COMMUNITY MENTAL HEALTH CENTERS PROGRAM FOR AN ADDITIONAL THREE YEARS, AND FOR THE HMD PROGRAM FOR ONE ADDITIONAL YEAR.
TO SUSPEND THE RULES AND PASS, AS AMENDED, S. 703, THE BILL IMPROVING THE ADMINISTRATION AND OPERATION OF THE OVERSEAS CITIZEN VOTING RIGHTS ACT OF 1975 AND THE FEDERAL VOTING ASSISTANCE ACT OF 1955.
TO SUSPEND THE RULES AND PASS, AS AMENDED, H.R. 12101, THE BILL EXTENDING FOR ONE YEAR THE AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS FOR "FARMER-TO-CONSUMER" DIRECT MARKETING PILOT PROJECTS.

TO AGREE TO THE CONFERENCE REPORT ON H.R. 12598, THE BILL AUTHORIZING APPROPRIATIONS FOR FISCAL YEAR 1979 TO THE DEPARTMENT OF STATE, THE INTERNATIONAL COMMUNICATION AGENCY, THE BOARD FOR INTERNATIONAL BROADCASTING AND RELATED PROGRAMS.

TO AGREE TO H. RES. 1323, THE RULE TO CONSIDER H.R. 1, THE BILL REQUIRING CANDIDATES FOR FEDERAL OFFICE, MEMBERS OF CONGRESS, AND OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES OF THE UNITED STATES TO FILE FINANCIAL STATEMENTS WITH THE COMPTROLLER GENERAL.
Issue1: Campaign Contributions, Lobbying/House Ethics Campaign Laws

description: TO AGREE TO SEVERAL AMENDMENTS TO H.R. 1, THE EFFECT OF WHICH WOULD BE TO REQUIRE CONGRESSIONAL CANDIDATES TO REPORT THE SOURCE AND TYPE OF THEIR INCOME BUT NOT THE AMOUNT.
Issue1: Campaign Contributions, Lobbying/House Ethics Campaign Laws

description: TO AMEND H.R. 1 BY REPEALING HOUSE RULE 47, THE RULE THAT LIMITS THE PERMISSABLE OUTSIDE INCOME OF MEMBERS OF CONGRESS TO NO MORE THAN 15% OF THEIR CONGRESSIONAL SALARIES, AND THAT LIMITS THEIR INCOME FROM HONORARIA TO NO MORE THAN $750 A YEAR.
Issue1: Campaign Contributions, Lobbying/House Ethics Campaign Laws

description: TO AMEND H.R. 1 BY STRIKING THE PROVISION THAT PROHIBITS ANY FORMER GOVERNMENT EMPLOYEE FROM MAKING BUSINESS CONTACTS WITH HIS/HER OLD AGENCY FOR ONE FULL YEAR AFTER LEAVING GOVERNMENT SERVICE.
Issue1: Campaign Contributions, Lobbying/House Ethics Campaign Laws

description: TO RECEDE FROM DISAGREEMENT WITH THE SENATE AMENDMENT TO H. CON. RES. 683, THE SECOND CONCURRENT RESOLUTION ON THE FEDERAL BUDGET FOR FISCAL YEAR 1979, AND CONCUR IN AN AMENDMENT THAT SETS TOTAL BUDGET AUTHORITY AT $555.65 BILLION, TOTAL OUTLAYS AT $487.5 BILLION, TOTAL REVENUES AT $448.7 BILLION AND THE TOTAL DEFICIT AT $38.8 BILLION. THE ORIGINAL SENATE AMENDMENT WOULD HAVE SET TOTAL BUDGET AUTHORITY AT $557.7 BILLION, TOTAL OUTLAYS AT $489.5 BILLION, TOTAL REVENUES AT $477.2 BILLION AND THE TOTAL DEFICIT AT $42.3 BILLION.

TO AMEND H.R. 12611, THE AIR SERVICE IMPROVEMENT ACT OF 1978, BY ALLOWING THE CIVIL AERONAUTICS BOARD TO DENY A NEW ROUTE AUTHORITY ONLY IF THE OPPOSING PARTY PRESENTS CLEAR AND CONVINCING EVIDENCE THAT THE NEW SERVICE WOULD NOT BE CONSISTENT WITH PUBLIC CONVENIENCE AND NECESSITY.
TO AMEND H.R. 12611 BY ELIMINATING THE MUTUAL AID PACT, A PACT THAT ALLOWED AIR CARRIERS TO POOL REVENUES FOR THE PURPOSE OF SUPPORTING OTHER AIR CARRIERS WHOSE EMPLOYEES WERE ON STRIKE.

TO AMEND H.R. 11733, THE SURFACE TRANSPORTATION ASSISTANCE ACT OF 1978, BY REQUIRING THAT THE ANNUAL AUTHORIZATION FOR PROGRAMS TO BE FINANCED BY THE HIGHWAY TRUST FUND MUST BE CLOSELY RELATED TO ANTICIPATED ANNUAL RECEIPTS.

TO MODIFY THE JEFFORDS SUBSTITUTE AMENDMENT TO H.R. 12452, THE COMPREHENSIVE EMPLOYMENT AND TRAINING ACT (CETA) AMENDMENTS OF 1978.  THE MODIFYING FLIPPO AMENDMENT INCREASES THE TARGET FOR THE TOTAL NUMBER OF CETA JOBS TO BE OFFERED FROM 20% TO 25% OF THE UNEMPLOYED POPULATION ABOVE AND BEYOND THE EXPECTED UNEMPLOYED POPULATION OF THE TOTAL WORK FORCE.  THE JEFFORDS SUBSTITUTE AMENDMENT PROVIDES FOR A GRADUAL SHIFTING OF 25% OF ALL CETA EMPLOYEES TO WORK TRAINING PROGRAMS, PLACES A TWO YEAR LIMIT ON CETA PROJECTS, LIMITS A PERSON'S PARTICIPATION IN A CETA JOB TO NO MORE THAN 18 MONTHS IN A FIVE-YEAR PERIOD, AND INDEXES CETA WAGES ON AVERAGE LOCAL WAGES RATHER THAN ON THE CONSUMER PRICE INDEX.

TO RECOMMIT H.R. 12452 TO THE COMMITTEE ON EDUCATION AND LABOR WITH INSTRUCTIONS TO REPORT IT BACK FORTHWITH WITH AN AMENDMENT LIMITING THE APPROPRIATION FOR PUBLIC SERVICE EMPLOYMENT PROGRAMS TO NO MORE THAN 30% OF THE TOTAL AMOUNT OF THE BILL'S FUNDING.

TO AGREE TO SEVERAL AMENDMENTS TO H.R. 11733, THE SURFACE TRANSPORTATION ASSISTANCE ACT OF 1978.  THE KOSTMAYER AMENDMENTS DELETE LANGUAGE THAT MANDATES FEDERAL COMPENSATION FOR BILLBOARDS REMOVED IN COMPLIANCE WITH THE HIGHWAY BEAUTIFICATION ACT AND FOR BILLBOARDS REMOVED AS A RESULT OF LOCAL ZONING AND LAND USE ORDINANCES.
TO SUSPEND THE RULES AND PASS, AS AMENDED, H.R. 10584, THE BILL DESIGNED TO STRENGHTHEN THE ECONOMY OF THE UNITED STATES THROUGH INCREASED SALES ABROAD OF AMERICAN FARM PRODUCTS.
TO SUSPEND THE RULES AND PASS, AS AMENDED, H.R. 11870, THE BILL AUTHORIZING APPROXIMATELY $1 MILLION FOR FISCAL YEAR 1979 FOR DOMESTIC TRAVEL PROGRAMS ADMINISTERED BY THE DEPARTMENT OF COMMERCE.

TO SUSPEND THE RULES AND PASS, AS AMENDED, H.R. 13655, THE BILL EXTENDING THROUGH FISCAL YEAR 1981 THE AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS FOR THE ESTABLISHMENT AND OPERATION OF HEALTH MAINTENANCE ORGANIZATIONS.
TO SUSPEND THE RULES AND PASS, AS AMENDED, H.R. 12584, THE BILL ESTABLISHING A NATIONAL CENTER FOR HEALTH CARE TECHNOLOGY AND EXTENDING AUTHORIZATIONS FOR HEALTH SERVICES RESEARCH.
TO SUSPEND THE RULES AND PASS, AS AMENDED H.R. 12370, THE BILL REVISING AND EXTENDING FOR THREE YEARS CERTAIN HEALTH SERVICE AND FAMILY PLANNING PROGRAMS.

TO SUSPEND THE RULES AND PASS, AS AMENDED, H.R. 13597, THE BILL AUTHORIZING $3 MILLION FOR THE AUTHORIZATION OF SOLAR COLLECTORS TO FURNISH A PORTION OF THE ENERGY NEEDS OF THE RAYBURN HOUSE OFFICE BUILDING AND THE HOUSE OFFICE BUILDING ANNEX NO. 2.
TO SUSPEND THE RULES AND PASS, AS AMENDED, H.R. 13488, THE BILL AMENDING THE INTERNAL REVENUE CODE OF 1954 WITH RESPECT TO THE TAXATION OF THE EARNED INCOME OF AMERICANS WORKING ABROAD.
TO SUSPEND THE RULES AND PASS, AS AMENDED, H.R. 9333, THE BILL AUTHORIZING THE SECRETARY OF THE INTERIOR TO CONSTRUCT HYDROELECTRIC POWERPLANTS AND MODIFY EXISTING WATER PROJECTS.
TO SUSPEND THE RULES AND PASS, AS AMENDED, H.R. 12728, THE BILL AUTHORIZING THE MINTING OF A NEW, LIGHTER ONE-DOLLAR COIN THAT WILL BEAR THE LIKENESS OF SUSAN B. ANTHONY.

TO AMEND H.R. 12005, THE BILL AUTHORIZING APPROPRIATIONS TO THE DEPARTMENT OF JUSTICE FOR FISCAL YEAR 1979.  THE COLLINS AMENDMENT PROHIBITS THE USE OF THESE FUNDS TO ENFORCE BUSING OF STUDENTS TO SCHOOLS OTHER THAN THE SCHOOLS NEAREST TO THEIR HOMES, EXCEPT FOR CASES INVOLVING BUSING OF MENTALLY OR PHYSICALLY HANDICAPPED CHILDREN.
THAT THE HOUSE RESOLVE ITSELF INTO THE COMMITTEE OF THE WHOLE FOR THE FURTHER CONSIDERATION OF H.R. 1, THE ETHICS IN GOVERNMENT ACT OF 1978.
Issue1: Campaign Contributions, Lobbying/House Ethics Campaign Laws

description: TO AMEND H.R. 1 BY AUTHORIZING ONLY THE DIRECTOR OF THE OFFICE OF GOVERNMENT ETHICS TO REVIEW THE FINANCIAL REPORTS OF THE MEMBERS OF THE INTELLIGENCE COMMUNITY.  THE MAZZOLI AMENDMENT ALSO ALLOWS MEMBERS OF THE INTELLIGENCE COMMUNITY, FOR SECURITY REASONS, TO FALSIFY ONLY THE INFORMATION ON THEIR OSTENSIBLE EMPLOYERS AND ON THEIR SALARIES.
TO AMEND H.R. 1 BY REDUCING THE CRIMINAL PENALTIES FOR PERSONS THAT FALSIFY THEIR FINANCIAL REPORTS OR MISUSE THE INFORMATION CONTAINED THEREIN.
Issue1: Campaign Contributions, Lobbying/House Ethics Campaign Laws

description: TO AMEND H.R. 1 BY EXEMPTING JUDGES AND DESIGNATED OFFICERS AND OFFICIALS IN THE JUDICIAL BRANCH OF THE GOVERNMENT FROM THE PROVISIONS OF THIS BILL.
Issue1: Campaign Contributions, Lobbying/House Ethics Campaign Laws

description: TO AGREE TO THE CONFERENCE REPORT ON H.R. 9214, THE BILL AMENDING THE BRETTON WOODS AGREEMENT ACT IN ORDER TO AUTHORIZE U.S. PARTICIPATION IN THE SUPPLEMENTARY FINANCING FACILITY OF THE INTERNATIONAL MONETARY FUND.

TO AMEND H.R. 12005, THE BILL AUTHORIZING APPROPRIATIONS TO THE DEPARTMENT OF JUSTICE FOR FISCAL YEAR 1979, BY REQUIRING THE ATTORNEY GENERAL TO ESTABLISH PROCEDURES THROUGH WHICH HE COULD ADVISE THE PRESIDENT ON THE MERIT SELECTION OF FEDERAL DISTRICT COURT JUDGES.

TO CONCUR, WITH AMENDMENT, IN SENATE AMENDMENT #9 TO THE CONFERENCE REPORT ON H.R. 12934.  THE MODIFIED SENATE AMENDMENT RAISES THE APPROPRIATION FOR U.S. CONTRIBUTIONS TO INTERNATIONAL MULTILATERAL ORGANIZATIONS FROM $327,676,000 TO $355,392,000.

TO RECEDE AND CONCUR, WITH AMENDMENT, IN SENATE AMENDMENT #123 TO THE CONFERENCE REPORT ON H.R. 12934.  THIS MODIFIED SENATE AMENDMENT AUTHORIZES THE ATTORNEY GENERAL TO ADMIT INTO THE UNITED STATES 7,5000 CAMBODIAN REFUGEES IN EACH OF THE YEARS 1979 AND 1980.
TO AMEND H.R. 14042, THE BILL AUTHORIZING APPROPRIATIONS TO THE DEPARTMENT OF DEFENSE FOR FISCAL YEAR 1979, BY STRIKING A $209 MILLION AUTHORIZATION FOR THE SETTLEMENT OF CERTAIN SHIPBUILDING CLAIMS.

TO RECEDE AND CONCUR, WITH AMENDMENT, IN SENATE AMENDMENT #31 TO THE CONFERENCE REPORT ON H.R. 12930.  THE MODIFIED SENATE AMENDMENT LIMITS THE POSSIBLE SALARY INCREASE FOR FEDERAL BLUE-COLLAR WORKERS TO NO MORE THAN 5.5%.
TO AGREE TO THE CONFERENCE REPORT ON H.R. 11302, THE BILL AUTHORIZING APPROPRIATIONS FOR RESEARCH, DEVELOPMENT, AND DEMONSTRATION PROGRAMS OF THE ENVIROMENTAL PROTECTION AGENCY FOR FISCAL YEAR 1979.

TO ORDER THE PREVIOUS QUESTION ON THE RODINO MOTION TO RECEDE AND CONCUR, WITH AMENDMENT, IN A SENATE AMENDMENT TO THE CONFERENCE REPORT ON H.R. 7843, THE BILL PROVIDING FOR THE APPOINTMENT OF ADDITIONAL DISTRICT AND CIRCUT COURT JUDGES.  (SEE RC 867)

TO RECEDE AND CONCUR, WITH AMENDMENT, TO A SENATE AMENDMENT TO THE CONFERENCE REPORT ON H.R. 7843, THE BILL PROVIDING FOR THE APPOINTMENT OF ADDITIONAL DISTRICT AND CIRCUT COURT JUDGES.  THE MODIFIED SENATE AMENDMENT PROVIDES FOR THE CREATION OF 177 NEW FEDERAL DISTRICT COURT JUDGESHIPS AND 35 ADDITIONAL APPELLATE JUDGESHIPS.

TO AMEND H.R. 14042, THE BILL AUTHORIZING APPROPRIATIONS TO THE DEPARTMENT OF DEFENSE FOR FISCAL YEAR 1979, BY REQUIRING TWO-HOUSE APPROVAL OF CONTRACT CLAIMS IN EXCESS OF $25 MILLION THAT ARE MADE UNDER PL 85-804.
TO OVERRIDE THE PRESIDENT'S VETO AND PASS H.R. 12928, THE BILL MAKING APPROPRIATIONS FOR PUBLIC WORKS, FOR WATER AND POWER DEVELOPMENT AND FOR ENERGY RESEARCH IN FISCAL YEAR 1979.

TO TABLE THE DICKINSON MOTION TO INSTRUCT THE HOUSE CONFEREES ON H.R. 13635 TO INSIST ON HOUSE LANGUAGE CONCERNING THE CONSOLIDATION OF ARMY AND NAVY HELICOPTER TRAINING PROGRAMS.  H.R. 13635 IS THE BILL MAKING APPROPRIATIONS FOR THE DEPARTMENT OF DEFENSE FOR FISCAL YEAR 1979.

TO RECEDE AND CONCUR IN SENATE AMENDMENT #49 TO THE CONFERENCE REPORT ON H.R. 12932, THE BILL MAKING APPROPRIATIONS FOR THE DEPARTMENT OF THE INTERIOR AND RELATED AGENCIES FOR FISCAL YEAR 1979.  SENATE AMENDMENT #49 EXEMPTS CERTAIN WATER PROJECTS IN THE COLORADO BASIN FROM FILING A BASINWIDE ENVIROMENTAL IMPACT STATEMENT, AS REQUIRED BY THE NATIONAL ENVIROMENTAL POLICY ACT.

TO AMEND H.R. 13471, THE FINANCIAL INSTITUTIONS REGULATORY ACT OF 1978, BY REQUIRING THE REIMBURSEMENT OF ATTORNEYS' FEES AND OTHER COSTS OF LITIGATION FOR PERSONS WHO WIN APPEALS AGAINST FEDERAL INSTITUTIONS COVERED BY THIS ACT.

TO AGREE TO SEVERAL AMENDMENTS TO H.R. 13471, THE EFFECT OF WHICH IS TO DELETE THE GRANDFATHER CLAUSE FOR ALL BANK HOLDING COMPANY INSURANCE AFFILIATES WHICH HAD APPLIED, BEFORE JUNE 6, 1978, FOR AUTHORITY TO ENGAGE IN INSURANCE ACTIVITIES.

TO AGREE TO H. RES. 1404, A RESOLUTION AUTHORIZING THE SPEAKER OF THE HOUSE TO DECLARE A RECESS AND ENTERTAIN MOTIONS TO SUSPEND THE RULES AT ANY TIME.  UNDER H. RES. 1404, THE HOUSE MAY ALSO CONSIDER CONFERENCE REPORTS AND AMENDMENTS REPORTED IN DISAGREEMENT ON THE SAME DAY THAT THEY ARE FILED.  THE PROVISIONS OF H. RES. 1404 ARE ONLY EFFECTIVE THROUGH OCT. 15, 1978.
TO AGREE TO H. RES. 1410, THE RULE TO CONSIDER H.R. 12422, THE BILL EXTENDING THE CONSUMER PRODUCT SAFETY ACT FOR AN ADDITIONAL THREE FISCAL YEARS.

TO MODIFY THE COMMITTEE SUBSTITUTE FOR TITLE II OF H.R 13750, THE SUGAR STABILIZATION ACT OF 1978.  THE MODIFYING STEIGER AMENDMENT ADDS A COST OF PRODUCTION ESCALATOR TO THE SUPPORT PRICE PROVISIONS OF THE BILL. THE WAYS AND MEANS COMMITTEE SUBSTITUTE IS DESIGNED TO OBTAIN A 15-CENT PRICE OBJECTIVE (PER POUND OF RAW SUGAR) THROUGH THE IMPOSITION OF SPECIAL IMPORT DUTIES.
TO AMEND H.R. 11545, THE MEAT IMPORT ACT OF 1978, BY SETTING THE MINIMUM LEVEL OF MEAT IMPORTS AT 739 MILLION POUNDS PER YEAR RATHER THAN 1.2 BILLION POUNDS PER YEAR.

TO RECOMMIT THE CONFERENCE REPORT ON H.R. 12929, THE BILL MAKING APPROPRIATIONS TO THE DEPARTMENTS OF LABOR, AND OF HEALTH, EDUCATION AND WELFARE FOR FISCAL YEAR 1979, WITH INSTRUCTIONS TO RECEDE AND CONCUR IN SENATE AMENDMENT #110 TO THE BILL. SENATE AMENDMENT #110 PROHIBITS THE USE OF THESE FUNDS TO IMPLEMENT AFFIRMATIVE ACTION ADMISSION POLICIES AT INSTITUTIONS OF HIGHER EDUCATION.

TO RECEDE AND CONCUR, WITH AMENDMENT, IN SENATE AMENDMENT #103 TO THE CONFERENCE REPORT ON H.R. 12929.  AMENDMENT #103, AS MODIFIED, PROHIBITS THE USE OF THESE FUNDS FOR ABORTIONS EXCEPT WHEN THE LIFE OF THE MOTHER WOULD BE ENDANGERED IF THE FETUS WERE CARRIED TO TERM, OR WHEN SEVERE AND LONG-LASTING PHYSICAL HEALTH DAMAGE WOULD OCCUR TO THE MOTHER IF THE PREGNANCY WERE CARRIED TO TERM, OR WHEN THE MOTHER IS THE VICTIM OF RAPE OR INCEST AND HAS REPORTED THE INCIDENT PROMPTLY TO A LAW ENFORCEMENT AGENCY.

TO INSTRUCT THE HOUSE CONFEREES ON H.R. 13511, THE REVENUE ACT OF 1978, TO CONCUR IN THE SENATE (NUNN-CHILES-BELLMON- ROTH) AMENDMENT TO THE BILL.  THE SENATE AMENDMENT PROVIDES FOR A 5% ACROSS-THE-BOARD TAX CUT FOR EACH OF FISCAL YEARS 1980 THROUGH 1983, PROVIDED THAT THE NATIONAL OUTLAYS INCREASE BY NO MORE THAN 1% ANUALLY, AND PROVIDED THAT THERE IS A BALANCED BUDGET BY FISCAL YEAR 1982.
TO REJECT TITLE VI OF THE CONFERENCE REPORT ON S. 555, THE ETHICS IN GOVERNMENT ACT OF 1978.  TITLE VI ESTABLISHES PROCEDURES FOR SPECIAL PROSECUTION OF EXECUTIVE DEPARTMENT PERSONNEL.
Issue1: Campaign Contributions, Lobbying/House Ethics Campaign Laws

description: TO SUSPEND THE RULES AND PASS, AS AMENDED, S. 957, THE BILL ESTABLISHING A PROGRAM TO IMPROVE AND MAINTAIN MORE EFFECTIVE PROCEDURES FOR THE RESOLUTION OF CONSUMER CONTROVERSIES IN SMALL CLAIMS COURTS.

TO SUSPEND THE RULES AND PASS, AS AMENDED, S. 1503, THE BILL PROVIDING FOR THE PAYMENT OF LOSSES INCURRED AS A RESULT OF THE BAN ON THE USE OF THE CHEMICAL TRIS IN APPAREL, FABRIC, YARN, OR OTHER FIBERS.

TO RECOMMIT THE CONFERENCE REPORT ON H.R. 12050 TO THE COMMITTEE OF CONFERENCE WITH INSTRUCTIONS THAT THE HOUSE CONFEREES INSIST ON HOUSE LANGUAGE THAT EXTENDS THE BILL TO COVER TUITION PAID TO ELEMENTARY AND SECONDARY SCHOOLS.  H.R. 12050 AMENDS THE INTERNAL REVENUE CODE OF 1954 SO AS TO PROVIDE FOR A FEDERAL INCOME TAX CREDIT FOR TUITION.

TO ORDER A SECOND ON THE ULLMAN MOTION TO SUSPEND THE RULES AND AGREE TO H. RES. 1432, THE RESOLUTION PROVIDING FOR HOUSE AGREEMENT TO H.R. 8533 AND THE SENATE AMENDMENT THERETO.  H.R. 8533 AMENDS THE INTERNAL REVENUE CODE OF 1954 SO AS TO PROVIDE TAX EXEMPTIONS FOR CERTAIN STATES THAT CONDUCT STATE-WIDE BINGO GAMES.  THE SENATE AMENDMENT, WHICH DEALS WITH CERTAIN NAVIGATION DEVELOPMENT ISSUES, AUTHORIZES THE REPLACEMENT OF LOCKS AND DAM 26 ON THE MISSISSIPPI RIVER AND PROVIDES FOR THE IMPOSITION OF INLAND WATERWAY USER TAXES.

TO ORDER THE PREVIOUS QUESTION ON H. RES. 1434, THE RESOLUTION PROVIDING FOR THE CONSIDERATION EN BLOC OF THE CONFERENCE REPORTS ON H.R. 4018, H.R. 5146, H.R. 5037, H.R. 5289 AND H.R. 5263.  THESE FIVE ENERGY CONFERENCE REPORTS DEAL WITH ENERGY TAXES, UTILITY RATE REFORM, NATURAL GAS PRICING, COAL CONVERSION, AND OTHER RELATED ISSUES OF ENERGY CONSERVATION AND REFORM.

TO AGREE TO H. RES. 1414, A RESOLUTION PROVIDING FOR THE ADOPTION OF A REPORT FILED BY THE COMMITTEE ON STANDARDS OF OFFICIAL CONDUCT THAT REPRIMANDS REPRESENTATIVE CHARLES H. WILSON OF CALIFORNIA FOR HIS FAILURE TO REPORT A WEDDING GIFT OF $1,000 THAT HE RECEIVED FROM TONGSUN PARK IN 1975.

TO RECOMMIT H. RES. 1416 TO THE COMMITTEE ON STANDARDS OF OFFICIAL CONDUCT WITH INSTRUCTIONS TO REPORT IT BACK FORTHWITH AFTER STRIKING ALL AFTER THE ENACTING CLAUSE AND INSERTING LANGUAGE THAT REPRIMANDS REPRESENTATIVE EDWARD R. ROYBAL FOR FALSELY TESTIFYING ON SEVERAL OCCASIONS ABOUT GIFTS RECEIVED FROM TONGSUN PARK.  THE ORIGINAL RESOLUTION WOULD HAVE CENSURED MR. ROYBAL.

TO RECOMMIT H.R. 12370 TO THE COMMITTEE ON INTERSTATE AND FOREIGN COMMERCE WITH INSTRUCTIONS TO REPORT IT BACK FORTHWITH WITH AN AMENDMENT PROHIBITING THE USE OF THESE FUNDS FOR ANY PROGRAM PROVIDING ABORTIONS, ABORTION COUNSELING, OR ABORTION REFERRAL SERVICES.

TO AMEND H.R. 14104, THE BILL EXTENDING APPROPRIATIONS FOR THE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT THROUGH FISCAL YEAR 1981.  THE DUNCAN AMENDMENT EXEMPTS THE TELLICO DAM AND RESERVOIR PROJECT FROM THE PROVISIONS OF THE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT.

TO CONCUR IN THE MODIFIED SENATE AMENDMENT TO THE CONFERENCE REPORT ON H.R.  12929, THE BILL MAKING APPROPRIATIONS FOR THE DEPARTMENTS OF LABOR AND OF HEALTH, EDUCATION, AND WELFARE FOR FISCAL YEAR 1979.  THE MODIFIED SENATE AMENDMENT PROHIBITS THE USE OF THESE FUNDS FOR ABORTIONS EXCEPT WHEN THE LIFE OF THE MOTHER WOULD BE ENDANGERED IF THE FETUS WERE CARRIED TO TERM, OR WHEN SEVERE AND LONG-LASTING PHYSICAL HEALTH DAMAGE WOULD OCCUR TO THE MOTHER IF THE PREGNANCY WERE COMPLETED, OR WHEN THE MOTHER IS A VICTIM OF RAPE OR INCEST AND HAS PROMPTLY REPORTED THE INCIDENT TO A LAW ENFORCEMENT AGENCY.  (THIS AMENDMENT WAS PREVIOUSLY REJECTED BY THE HOUSE ON OCT. 12, 1978.  SEE RC 895.)

TO AMEND THE FORD(MI) SUBSTITUTE FOR H.R. 11274, THE MIDDLE INCOME STUDENT ASSISTENCE ACT.  THE ERLENBORN AMENDMENT WOULD ALLOW ONLY STUDENTS FROM FAMILIES WITH AN ADJUSTED GROSS INCOME OF LESS THAN $40,000 TO APPLY FOR INTEREST SUBSIDIES ON GUARANTEED STUDENT LOANS.  THE FORD SUBSTITUTE FOR THE BILL INCORPORATES EIGHT CHANGES THAT WILL BRING H.R. 11274 INTO CLOSER CONFORMITY WITH ITS SENATE COMPANION BILL S. 2539, THE COLLEGE OPPORTUNITY ACT OF 1978.

TO ORDER A SECOND ON THE ST. GERMAIN MOTION TO SUSPEND THE RULES AND AGREE TO H. RES. 1439, THE RESOLUTION STATING THAT THE HOUSE CONCURS, WITH AMENDMENTS, IN THE SENATE AMENDMENTS TO H.R. 14279, THE FINANCIAL INSTITUTIONS REGULATORY AND INTEREST RATE CONTROL ACT OF 1978.  (SEE RC 930)

TO SUSPEND THE RULES AND AGREE TO H. RES. 1439, THE RESOLUTION STATING THAT THE HOUSE CONCURS, WITH AMENDMENTS, IN THE SENATE AMENDMENTS TO H.R. 14279, THE FINANCIAL INSTITUTIONS REGULATORY AND INTEREST RATE CONTROL ACT OF 1978.  THE BILL, AS MODIFIED, ESTABLISHES A FEDERAL FINANCIAL INSTITUTIONS EXAMINATION COUNCIL, STRENGTHENS THE AUTHORITY OF FEDERAL AGENCIES WHICH REGULATE DEPOSITORY INSTITUTIONS, PROHIBITS INTERLOCKING MANAGEMENT AND DIRECTOR RELATIONSHIPS BETWEEN FINANCIAL INSTITUTIONS, AND MAKES VARIOUS OTHER CHANGES IN FEDERAL BANKING LAWS.

TO AGREE TO THE CONFERENCE REPORTS ON H.R. 4018, H.R. 5146, H.R. 5037, H.R. 5289 AND H.R. 5263.  THESE FIVE ENERGY CONFERENCE REPORTS DEAL WITH ENERGY TAX REFORM, UTILITY RATE REFORM, NATURAL GAS PRICING, COAL CONVERSION, AND RELATED ISSUES OF ENERGY CONSERVATION AND REFORM.

TO SUSPEND THE RULES AND CONCUR IN THE SENATE AMENDMENTS TO H.R. 10979, THE EMERGENCY HIGHWAY AND TRANSPORTATION REPAIR ACT OF 1978.  THE SENATE AMENDMENTS ADD COMPROMISE LANGUAGE ON PUBLIC WORKS SPENDING AND AUTHORIZE $1.4 BILLION FOR 158 WATER PROJECTS IN 46 STATES.  (THIS MOTION FAILED DUE TO LACK OF A QUORUM.)
TO AMEND H.R. 6689 BY REDUCING BY $90,000 THE AUTHORIZATION MADE FOR THE EXPANSION OF STAFF OF THE WASHINGTON OFFICE OF ANDREW YOUNG, THE U.S. AMBASSADOR TO THE UNITED NATIONS.
TO AMEND H.R. 6689 BY PROHIBITING THAT ANY OF THE AUTHORIZED FUNDS BE USED FOR AID OR REPARATIONS TO  VIETNAM.
TO PASS H.R. 6689.
TO AMEND H. CON. RES. 213 BY INCREASING THE DEFENSE BUDGET AUTHORITY BY $2 BILLION AND  THE DEFENSE OUTLAYS BY $1 BILLION.
TO AMEND H. CON. RES. 214 BY INCREASING THE DEFENSE BUDGET AUTHORITY AND THE DEFENSE OUTLAYS  BY $1 BILLION EACH.
TO AMEND H. CON. RES. 214 BY DECREASING THE DEFENSE BUDGET AUTHORITY BY $1.15 BILLION AND OUTLAYS  BY $300 MILLION.
TO AMEND H. CON. RES. 214 BY INCREASING THE BUDGET AUTHORITY AND OUTLAYS  FOR VETERANS' AFFAIRS BY $175 MILLION EACH.

TO AGREE TO AN AMENDMENT TO S. RES. 110 THAT WOULD ALTER THOSE SECTIONS OF THE  BILL DEALING WITH FINANCIAL DISCLOSURE SO THAT INCOME TAX RETURNS MUST BE DISCLOSED. THE WEICKER AMENDMENT ALSO WOULD DELETE THE RESTRICTION ON OUTSIDE EARNED INCOME.

TO TABLE THE DURKIN AMENDMENT TO S. RES. 110, AN AMENDMENT WHICH WOULD  PROHIBIT SENATORS FROM RECEIVING HONORARIA FROM ANY GROUP OR PERSON WITH A DIRECT INTEREST IN LEGISLATION. (CQ MARCH 26, 1977, PG. 580)

TO TABLE THE SCHMITT AMENDMENT TO S. RES. 110.  THE SCHMITT AMENDMENT WOULD  REQUIRE ANNUAL DISCLOSURE OF THE ASSETS AND LIABILITIES, GROSS INCOME, TAXABLE INCOME AND INCOME TAX OF EACH SENATOR.  (CQ MARCH 26, 1977, PG. 580

TO AGREE TO AN AMENDMENT TO S. RES. 110 THAT REQUIRES THAT THE INCOME AND INTERESTS OF A SPOUSE OR A DEPENDENT OF A SENATE MEMBER OR SENATE EMPLOYEE BE REPORTED IF THOSE INTERESTS ARE "WITHIN THE CONSTRUCTIVE CONTROL OF THE REPORTING INDIVIDUAL."
TO TABLE THE STEVENSON AMENDMENT TO S. RES. 110.  THE STEVENSON AMENDMENT CONTAINS SUBSTITUTE LANGUAGE FOR THE SECTION OF THE BILL THAT PROHIBITS USE OF UNOFFICIAL OFFICE ACCOUNTS.

TO TABLE THE TOWER UNPRINTED AMENDMENT #96 TO S. RES. 110. THE TOWER AMENDMENT WOULD PROHIBIT THOSE SENATORS OR EMPLOYEES RECEIVING SALARIES IN EXCESS OF $35,000 A YEAR FROM ACCEPTING PAYMENTS FROM THE FEDERAL TREASURY OR ANY OTHER FEDERALLY REGULATED ENTERPRISES.

TO TABLE THE TOWER UNPRINTED AMENDMENT #97 TO S. RES. 110. THE TOWER AMENDMENT #97 IS SIMILAR TO #96 (SEE RC 71) WITH THE EXCEPTION THAT IT ALLOWS SENATE MEMBERS TO HAVE UNEARNED INCOME OF UP TO 15% OF THEIR SALARIES FROM SUBSIDIES OR FEDERALLY REGULATED ENTERPRISES.
TO TABLE THE DURKIN AMENDMENT #103 TO S. RES. 110, AN AMENDMENT  EXEMPTING EARNED INCOME FROM FAMILY OWNED ENTERPRISES FROM THE ESTABLISHED EARNED INCOME LIMIT.

TO TABLE THE DURKIN AMENDMENT #104 TO S. RES. 110.  THIS AMENDMENT DECLARES  THE LEGISLATIVE ACTIONS OF ANY SENATOR UNETHICAL WHEN HE/SHE IS INTRODUCING OR PUSHING ANY LEGISLATION WITH THE PRIMARY OR SECONDARY PURPOSE OF FURTHERANCE OF HIS/HER FAMILY'S OR HIS/HER OWN PECUNIARY INTERESTS.
Issue2: Campaign Contributions, Lobbying/House Ethics Campaign Laws

description: TO TABLE THE ROTH AMENDMENT #100 TO S. RES. 110, AN AMENDMENT DESIGNED TO  ESTABLISH A THREE MEMBER CITIZEN ADVISORY COMMISSION ON ETHICS TO ASSIST THE SELECT COMMITTEE ON ETHICS IN INVESTIGATION OF SERIOUS ALLEGATIONS OF WRONGDOING.
Issue2: Campaign Contributions, Lobbying/House Ethics Campaign Laws

description: TO TABLE THE BELLMON AMENDMENT #120 TO S. RES. 110.  THIS AMENDMENT WOULD  STRIKE LANGUAGE IN THE BILL THAT PROHIBITS MEMBERS OF THE SENATE FROM ENGAGING IN PROFESSIONAL PRACTICES.
Issue2: Campaign Contributions, Lobbying/House Ethics Campaign Laws

description: TO TABLE THE HELMS AMENDMENT #112 TO S. RES. 110.  THE HELMS AMENDMENT WOULD  INCREASE FROM 60 TO 90 DAYS THE PERIOD BEFORE A PRIMARY ELECTION AND FROM 60 TO 180 DAYS THE PERIOD BEFORE A GENERAL ELECTION IN WHICH ANY SENATOR COULD SEND OUT A MASS MAILING.
TO AMEND S. RES. 110 BY REQUIRING THAT COST-TO-THE-PUBLIC INFORMATION BE  PRINTED ON THE FRONT PAGE OF NEWSLETTERS PRINTED AT GOVERNMENT EXPENSE.
TO TABLE THE HELMS AMENDMENT #113 TO S. RES. 110, AN AMENDMENT TO LIMIT THE DISTRIBUTION OF GOVERNMENT FUNDED NEWSLETTERS TO FOUR TIMES A YEAR.

TO TABLE THE PERCY AMENDMENT #133 TO S. RES. 110.  THE PERCY AMENDMENT WOULD HAVE  DELETED FROM THE BILL THOSE SECTIONS PROHIBITING MEMBERS OF CONGRESS FROM PRACTICING PROFESSIONAL SERVICES, BUT WOULD HAVE RETAINED THOSE SECTIONS PROHIBITING ACTIONS WHICH WOULD CONFLICT WITH THE PERFORMANCE OF THE OFFICIAL DUTIES OF EACH CONGRESSIONAL MEMBER.
Issue2: Campaign Contributions, Lobbying/House Ethics Campaign Laws

description: TO TABLE DIVISION 1 OF THE BARTLETT AMENDMENT TO H.R. 4800, A BILL TO EXTEND THE EMERGENCY UNEMPLOYMENT COMPENSATION ACT OF 1974 FOR AN ADDITIONAL YEAR.  THIS SECTION OF THE BARTLETT AMENDMENT WOULD REQUIRE APPROVAL OF BOTH  HOUSES PRIOR TO INSTALLING AN INCREASE IN CONGRESSIONAL SALARIES.
TO AGREE TO DIVISION 1 OF THE BARTLETT AMENDMENT (SEE RC 81) TO H.R. 4800.

TO TABLE DIVISION 2 OF THE BARTLETT AMENDMENT TO H.R. 4800. DIVISION 2 OF THE AMENDMENT WOULD HAVE REPEALED THE RECENT PAY RAISES GRANTED TO MEMBERS OF THE CONGRESS, THE FEDERAL JUDICIARY AND CERTAIN OTHER EMPLOYEES OF THE LEGISLATIVE AND EXECUTIVE BRANCHES OF THE FEDERAL GOVERNMENT.
TO AMEND H.R. 4800 BY PROVIDING FOR A THREE MONTH PHASE-OUT OF THE EMERGENCY UNEMPLOYMENT COMPENSATION PROGRAM AFTER MARCH 31, 1978.
TO AMEND H.R. 4800 BY DELETING THE COMMITTEE AMENDMENT THAT PROVIDES THAT THE COST OF THE PROGRAM WILL BE PAID FROM GENERAL REVENUES AFTER MARCH OF 1977.
TO PASS H.R. 4800.

TO TABLE THE TOWER AMENDMENT TO S. 1051, A BILL TO AMEND THE UNITED STATES GRAIN  STANDARDS ACT OF 1976.  THE TOWER AMENDMENT WOULD HAVE SPECIFIED CRITERIA FOR THE ADMINISTRATOR OF FGIS TO USE WHEN WAIVING THE REQUESTS OF BOARDS OF TRUST, CHAMBERS OF COMMERCE OR PRIVATE EXCHANGES THAT SEEK TO BE INSPECTION AGENTS OF FGIS.

TO PASS S. 1051, A BILL TO AMEND THE UNITED STATES GRAIN STANDARDS ACT OF 1976 SO  AS TO ELIMINATE CERTAIN RECORDKEEPING REQUIREMENTS AND SUPERVISION FEES.  THE BILL ALSO ESTABLISHES A TEMPORARY TWELVE MEMBER COMMITTEE TO ADVISE THE FEDERAL GRAIN INSPECTION SERVICE ADMINISTRATOR ON IMPLEMENTATION OF THE 1976 ACT.
TO AMEND S. RES. 110 BY ALLOWING CERTAIN JOURNEYS OF THE SENATORS TO BE PAID BY PRIVATE  FOREIGN EDUCATIONAL AND CHARITABLE INSTITUTIONS.
TO AMEND S. RES. 110 BY REQUIRING THE PRESENCE OF TWENTY-FIVE SENATORS ON THE FLOOR  AT ALL TIMES PRIOR TO MAKING ANY TRANSACTIONS OF SENATE BUSINESS.
TO DIRECT THE SERGEANT AT ARMS TO REQUEST THE ATTENDANCE OF ABSENT SENATORS.
TO TABLE THE HANSEN AMENDMENT TO S. RES. 110.  THE HANSEN AMENDMENT WOULD REQUIRE NONSPECIFIC FINANCIAL DISCLOSURE OF ALL PROPERTIES VALUED AT MORE THAN $500,000.
TO TABLE THE MODIFIED BAKER AMENDMENT TO S. RES. 110, AN AMENDMENT WHICH WOULD  TERMINATE THE PROVISIONS OF THE BILL ON MARCH 1, 1981.
TO PASS S. RES. 110.
TO ASCERTAIN THE GERMANENESS OF THE CHAPTER 2 COMMITTEE AMENDMENTS TO H.R. 4877, A BILL  MAKING THE FIRST REGULAR SUPPLEMENTAL APPROPRIATIONS FOR FISCAL YEAR 1977.
TO AMEND H.R. 4877 BY AUTHORIZING AN ADDITIONAL $5 MILLION IN APPROPRIATED FUNDS FOR  FAMILY PLANNING PROJECT GRANTS OF THE HEALTH SERVICES ADMINISTRATION.
TO AMEND H.R. 4877 BY STRIKING THE SECTION OF THE BILL THAT APPROPRIATES $241,000 TO THE COUNCIL ON WAGE AND PRICE STABILITY.
TO PASS H.R. 4877.
TO CONFIRM THE NOMINATION OF PETER F. FLAHERTY TO BE DEPUTY ATTORNEY GENERAL.
TO PASS, AS AMENDED, H.R. 1828, A BILL DELAYING UNTIL JANURARY 1, 1977 THE EFFECTIVE  DATE FOR CERTAIN SICK PAY EXCLUSIONS MADE BY THE TAX REFORM ACT OF 1976.
TO INSTRUCT THE SERGEANT AT ARMS TO REQUEST THE ATTENDANCE OF ABSENT SENATORS.
TO RECOMMIT H.R. 3477, PROPOSED TAX REDUCTION AND SIMPLIFICATION ACT, TO THE COMMITTEE ON FINANCE WITH INSTRUCTIONS TO DELETE SECTION 302, THE PROVISION FOR BUSINESS TAX INCENTIVES.

TO AMEND H.R. 3477 BY MAKING THE PROPOSED EMPLOYMENT TAX CREDIT AVAILABLE ONLY FOR  NEW EMPLOYEES THAT HAVE PREVIOUSLY BEEN UNEMPLOYED 26 WEEKS OR LONGER, AND BY RAISING THAT CREDIT TO 50% OF THE FIRST $4200 IN WAGES PAID OVER EXISTING LEVELS.
TO AGREE TO DIVISION 1 OF AN AMENDMENT TO H.R. 3477 THAT WOULD INCREASE THE NEW JOBS  TAX CREDIT FOR EACH NEW EMPLOYEE HIRED FROM 25% TO 50% OF THE FIRST $4200 IN WAGES PAID OVER EXISTING LEVELS.
TO AGREE TO DIVISION 2 OF AN AMENDMENT TO H.R. 3477 THAT WOULD INCREASE THE LIMIT ON THE NEW JOBS TAX CREDIT FROM $40,000 TO $100,000 PER EMPLOYER.
TO AMEND H.R. 3477 BY ALLOWING THAT TAXPAYERS 65 YEARS OR OLDER HAVE THE OPTION TO MAKE  CLAIMS FOR 1976 BY EITHER THE FORMER RETIREMENT INCOME CREDIT  OR THE NEWLY PROPOSED ELDERLY CREDIT.
TO AMEND H.R. 3477 BY PROVIDING FOR A PERMANENT TAX RATE REDUCTION TO 14% FOR ALL TAXABLE INCOME BRACKETS BELOW $20,000.
TO AMEND H.R. 3477 BY PROVIDING FOR A 10% CUT IN TAX RATES FOR ALL INCOME BRACKETS.
TO AMEND H.R. 3477 WITH A PROVISION FOR RESTORING TAX DEDUCTIONS FOR EXPENSES INCURRED IN  THE ATTENDANCE OF CERTAIN CONVENTIONS IN FOREIGN COUNTRIES WITHIN NORTH AMERICA.

TO AMEND H.R. 3477 BY ALLOWING THAT THE PRESENT 10% INVESTMENT TAX CREDIT BE ONE-THIRD  REFUNDABLE TO CERTAIN FIRMS.  THE KENNEDY AMENDMENT SUGGESTS A SUBSTITUTE FOR THE 12% INVESTMENT TAX CREDIT PROPOSED IN THE BILL.
TO AMEND H.R. 3477 BY DELETING THE SECTION THAT PROVIDES FOR A TEMPORARY INCREASE TO 12% OF THE INVESTMENT TAX CREDIT.
TO AMEND H.R. 3477 BY INSERTING A TAX CREDIT OF $250 FOR THOSE TAXPAYERS MAINTAINING AN ELDERLY DEPENDENT OF AGE 65 OR OLDER.
TO AMEND H.R. 3477 BY DELAYING UNTIL TAX YEAR 1978 THE EFFECTIVE DATE OF CHANGES IN THE TAX REFORM ACT FOR CERTAIN POULTRY FARMING CORPORATIONS.

TO AMEND H.R. 3477 BY PROVIDING THAT THOSE STATES WHICH HAVE HAD A 1976 UNEMPLOYMENT RATE  OF 7.5%  AND  WHOSE UNEMPLOYMENT PAYROLL HAS BEEN 101% OF THE PRIOR YEAR'S PAYROLL, SHALL BE ELIGIBLE FOR THE JOBS TAX CREDIT.
TO AMEND H.R. 3477 BY OMITTING FEDERAL, STATE, OR LOCAL AID TO A CHILD IN A  HOUSEHOLD FROM THE CALCULATIONS FOR EARNED INCOME CREDIT FOR THAT HOUSEHOLD.
TO AMEND H.R. 3477 BY ELIMINATING THE TAX INCREASES RETROACTIVE TO JANUARY 1, 1976.
TO TABLE THE HANSEN AMENDMENT TO H.R. 3477, AN AMENDMENT ALLOWING A MAXIMUM TAX  CREDIT OF $225 FOR EXPENSES INCURRED IN INSTALLING INSULATION AND OTHER ITEMS FOR HOME ENERGY CONSERVATION.
TO AMEND H.R. 3477 BY RAISING THE STANDARD DEDUCTION FOR SINGLE PERSONS FROM  $2,200 TO $2,400.
TO AMEND H.R. 3477 BY ALLOWING THAT THOSE PERSONS AND FIRMS WHO HAVE INVESTED  IN POLLUTION CONTROL EQUIPMENT MAY RECEIVE THE FULL INVESTMENT TAX CREDIT.
TO AMEND H.R. 3477 BY AUTOMATICALLY INDEXING TAX RATES, PERSONAL EXEMPTIONS,  AND STANDARD DEDUCTIONS ACCORDING TO INCREASES IN THE CONSUMER PRICE INDEX.
TO AMEND H.R. 3477 BY NO LONGER CLASSIFYING FIRST-CLASS AIR TRAVEL AS A LEGITIMATE  BUSINESS EXPENSE TAX DEDUCTION.
TO TABLE THE BENTSEN AMENDMENT TO H.R. 3477.  THE BENTSEN AMENDMENT MODIFIES THE METHODS FOR INCLUDING CERTAIN INTANGIBLE DRILLING EXPENSES AS DEDUCTIONS IN THE MINIMUM TAX.
TO AMEND H.R. 3477 BY ALLOWING ACCELERATED DEPRECIATION FOR INVESTMENTS IN HIGH  UNEMPLOYENT AREAS.
TO AMEND H.R. 3477 BY ARRANGING THAT THE DEDUCTIONS FOR CERTAIN INTANGIBLE OIL DRILLING  EXPENSES OF INDEPENDENT PRODUCERS BE RETROACTIVE TO 1976, AS WELL AS TO 1977 AND SUBSEQUENT YEARS.
TO TABLE THE ALLEN AMENDMENT TO H.R. 3477.  THE ALLEN AMENDMENT POSTPONES FOR ONE YEAR  THE EFFECTIVE DATE OF THE IRS RULING ON CERTAIN INVESTMENT ANNUITIES.
TO AGREE TO THE CONFERENCE REPORT ON H.R. 11, A BILL AUTHORIZING FUNDS FOR THE EMERGENCY  PUBLIC WORKS PROGRAMS.
TO AMEND H.R. 3477 BY EXTENDING FOR SIX QUARTERS UNTIL SEPTEMBER 30, 1978 THE  ANTI-RECESSION ASSISTANCE PROGRAM.
TO PASS H.R. 3477.
TO AMEND H.R. 4876, ECONOMIC STIMULUS SUPPLEMENTAL APPROPRIATIONS FOR FISCAL 1977,  BY REDUCING FUNDING FOR PUBLIC SERVICE JOBS BY $3.9 BILLION.

TO PASS, AS AMENDED, H.R. 4876.  THE MODIFIED BILL APPROPRIATES APPROXIMATELY  $20 BILLION FOR CERTAIN FEDERAL ECONOMIC STIMULUS PROGRAMS, INCLUDING SOME COMPONENTS OF THE PRESIDENT'S ECONOMIC STIMULUS PACKAGE.
TO PASS H.R. 4975, A BILL EXTENDING THROUGH FISCAL 1978 THE FUNDS FOR FEDERAL HEALTH  PLANNING PROGRAMS AND FOR CERTAIN BIOMEDICAL RESEARCH PROJECTS.
TO AMEND S. CON. RES. 19, THE BILL SETTING FORTH A U.S. CONGRESSIONAL BUDGET FOR FISCAL 1978, BY INCREASING TO $8.1 BILLION THE BUDGET AUTHORITY FOR COMMUNITY AND REGIONAL DEVELOPMENT PROGRAMS.
TO AMEND S. CON. RES. 19 BY INCREASING TO $179.9 BILLION THE OUTLAYS FOR INCOME SECURITY.
TO AGREE TO A MODIFIED AMENDMENT TO S. CON. RES. 19 THAT WOULD INCREASE BUDGET  AUTHORITY BY $500 MILLION AND OUTLAYS BY $400 MILLION FOR VETERANS' SERVICES AND BENEFITS.
TO AMEND S. CON. RES. 19 BY REDUCING THE FUNDING FOR CETA PUBLIC SERVICE JOBS PROGRAMS  BY $2 BILLION.
TO AMEND S. CON. RES. 19 BY RESTORING THE TOTAL FIGURES IN THE BUDGET TO THE LEVELS  FIRST APPROVED BY THE BUDGET COMMITTEE.
TO PASS S. CON. RES. 19.

TO AMEND S. 855, SENATE COMPANION BILL TO H.R. 4991, A BILL AUTHORIZING FUNDS FOR THE NATIONAL  SCIENCE FOUNDATION. THE HATCH AMENDMENT PROPOSES THAT EACH OF THE FIFTY STATES AND THE DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA RECEIVE NO LESS THAN .25% OF THE TOTAL FUNDS ALLOCATED FOR RESEARCH.

TO TABLE THE DURKIN AMENDMENT TO S. 69, SENATE COMPANION BILL TO H.R. 5840, THE BILL TO  REVISE THE EXPORT ADMINISTRATION ACT OF 1969.  THE DURKIN AMENDMENT WOULD PROHIBIT THE EXPORTATION OF ALASKAN OIL FOR TWO YEARS.

TO PASS H.R. 5840, THE REVISED VERSION OF THE EXPORT ADMINISTRATION ACT OF 1969.  THE REVISED  BILL IMPROVES THE ADMINISTRATION OF EXPORT CONTROLS AND STRENGTHENS ANTI-BOYCOTT PROVISIONS TO BE MAINTAINED WITH REGARD TO THE ARAB-ISRAELI BOYCOTT.
TO DIRECT THE SERGEANT AT ARMS TO REQUEST THE ATTENDANCE OF ABSENT SENATORS.

TO RECEDE FROM DISAGREEMENT AND CONCUR IN A CONFERENCE AMENDMENT TO S. CON. RES. 19 THAT SETS  1978 BUDGET TARGETS OF REVENUES OF $396.3 BILLION, BUDGET AUTHORITY OF $503.45 BILLION, OUTLAYS $460.95 BILLION AND A DEFICIT OF 64.65 BILLION.
TO AMEND H.R. 5970, A BILL AUTHORIZING FUNDS FOR MILITARY PROCUREMENT IN 1978, BY INCREASING  THE MINIMAL STRENGTH OF THE NAVAL RESERVE FROM 76,400 TROOPS TO 95,900 TROOPS.
TO PASS H.R. 5970, MILITARY PROCUREMENT AUTHORIZATIONS FOR 1978.

TO TABLE THE KENNEDY AMENDMENT TO S. 826, THE BILL CREATING A FEDERAL DEPARTMENT OF ENERGY.  THE  KENNEDY AMENDMENT WOULD AUTHORIZE THE AWARDING OF REASONABLE FEES TO ATTORNEYS AND OTHER PUBLIC PARTICIPANTS IN THE PROCEEDINGS OF THIS NEW AGENCY.
TO TABLE THE MCINTYRE AMENDMENT TO S. 826 THAT WOULD HAVE ESTABLISHED AN OFFICE OF SMALL BUSINESS  AFFAIRS IN THE DEPARTMENT OF ENERGY.

TO TABLE THE SCHWEIKER AMENDMENT TO S. 826.  THE SCHWEIKER AMENDMENT ADDS TO THE BILL  A SECTION THAT REQUIRES THAT CONGRESS APPROVE, WITHIN A SET PERIOD OF TIME, THE REGULATIONS ESTABLISHED BY THE NEW DEPARTMENT OF ENERGY.
TO PASS S. 826.

TO AMEND S. 7, A BILL TO ESTABLISH IN THE DEPARTMENT OF THE INTERIOR AN OFFICE OF  STRIP MINING RECLAMATION AND ENFORCEMENT.  THE JOHNSTON AMENDMENT #276 REDEFINES THE PREREQUISITES FOR RECOMPENSING OWNERS OF SURFACE LANDS THAT ARE AFFECTED BY GOVERNMENT STRIP MINING OPERATIONS.
TO AMEND S. 7 WITH AN AMENDMENT TO THE JOHNSTON AMENDMENT #277 (SEE RC 151) THAT WOULD  STRENGTHEN AND CLARIFY THE ENFORCEMENT PROCEDURES SET FORTH IN THE PROPOSAL OF THE SENATOR FROM LOUSIANA.
TO AMEND S. 7 BY PERMITTING THAT THE SEPARATE STATE GOVERNMENTS RETAIN THE RIGHT TO REGULATE SURFACE MINING AND RECLAMATION OPERATIONS IN THEIR RESPECTIVE STATES.

TO AGREE TO AN AMENDMENT IN THE NATURE OF A SUBSTITUTE TO THE JOHNSTON AMENDMENT #275  TO S. 7.  THE HART AMENDMENT WOULD PROHIBIT SURFACE MINING IN ALLUVIAL VALLEY FLOORS AND IN CERTAIN UNDEVELOPED RANGELANDS IN THE WEST.

TO AMEND S. 7 BY REQUIRING THAT THE STATES USE THE "ABANDONED MINE RECLAMATION FUND" FOR THE  PRIMARY PURPOSE OF FUNDING RECLAMATIONS OF ORPHANED LANDS, ABANDONED COAL LANDS AND OTHER QUALIFYING LANDS, AND THAT SECONDARY USE OF THE FUND  BE THEN RESTRICTED.

TO AMEND S. 7 BY VESTING IN THE STATES THE JURISDICTION OVER MATTERS OF LAND APPEARANCE  AND LAND USE, AS LONG AS THOSE DECISIONS DO NOT INFRINGE ON THE ENVIRONMENTAL, HEALTH OR SAFETY CONCERNS OF OTHERS.

TO AMEND S. 7 BY REQUIRING THAT THE STATES MEET THE FEDERAL RECLAMATION STANDARDS WITH  REGARD TO PUBLIC HEALTH, SAFETY, WATER DIMUNITION AND POLLUTION, BUT NOT WITH RESPECT TO LAND APPEARANCE AND CONTOUR.
TO AMEND S. 7 BY DELETING THE REQUIREMENT FOR WRITTEN CONSENT OF THE OWNERS OF  SURFACE LANDS THAT WILL BE AFFECTED BY GOVERNMENT MINING OPERATIONS.

TO AMEND S. 7 BY FACILITATING THE PROCESS BY WHICH ANY OPERATOR, PERMITEE OR FEE OWNER,  LESSOR OR LESSEE OF COAL DEPOSITS CAN INSTITUTE ACTIONS FOR DECLARATORY JUDGEMENT OR INJUNCTIVE RELIEF AS APPROPRIATE TO THE PROVISIONS OF THE BILL.
TO AMEND S. 7 BY GIVING TO THE STATES AND THE SECRETARY OF THE INTERIOR THE AUTHORITY AND DISCRETION TO GRANT PERMITS FOR LIMITED MINING ACTIVITY IN ALLUVIAL VALLEY FLOORS.
TO PASS H.R. 2, THE SURFACE MINING AND RECLAMATION ACT OF 1977, AFTER STRIKING ALL AFTER THE ENACTING CLAUSE AND INSERTING IN LIEU THEREOF THE TEXT OF S. 7.
TO TABLE THE THURMOND AMENDMENT TO S. 275, THE PROPOSED FOOD AND AGRICULTURE ACT.   THE THURMOND AMENDMENT WOULD PROHIBIT THE DISTRIBUTION OF FOOD STAMPS TO FARM EMPLOYEES WHO HAD GONE ON STRIKE.
TO AMEND S. 275 BY INCREASING THE TARGET PRICE FOR THE 1977 CORN CROP FROM  $1.70 PER BUSHEL TO $1.85 PER BUSHEL.
TO AMEND S. 275 BY MANDATING THE USE OF A PHOTO I.D. CARD, A NATIONAL  APPLICATION CROSS-CHECK AND AN EARNINGS CLEARANCE SYSTEM IN THE FOOD STAMP PROGRAM.
TO AMEND S. 275 BY EXTENDING THE DURATION OF THE FOOD STAMP PROGRAM FOR FIVE YEARS INSTEAD OF TWO.
TO AMEND S. 275 BY REDUCING THE TARGET PRICE FOR THE 1977 WHEAT CROP FROM $2.90 PER BUSHEL  TO $2.65 PER BUSHEL.

TO AMEND S. 275 BY RESTORING THE PURCHASE REQUIREMENT FOR FOOD STAMPS THAT IS NOW IN  EXISTING LAW.  THE PURCHASE REQUIREMENT STATES THAT A FAMILY OF FOUR WITH A POVERTY LEVEL INCOME MUST PAY UP TO 30% OF THEIR INCOME FOR THEIR MONTHLY ALLOWANCE OF $166 IN FOOD STAMPS.
TO AMEND S. 275 BY REDUCING THE TARGET PRICES FOR WHEAT AND FOR FEED GRAINS FOR FISCAL  YEARS 1979 THROUGH 1982.
TO AMEND S. 275 BY RESTRICTING THE ELIGIBILITY FOR FOOD STAMPS TO THOSE FAMILIES WHOSE INCOMES DO  NOT EXCEED 125% OF THE POVERTY LEVEL INCOME.
TO AMEND S. 275 BY FURTHER RESTRICTING THE AVAILABILITY OF FOOD STAMPS TO COLLEGE STUDENTS.
TO PASS S. 275.

TO PASS, AS AMENDED, H.R. 6138, THE YOUTH EMPLOYMENT AND TRAINING ACT OF 1977, A BILL  WHICH AMENDS THE CETA ACT OF 1973 BY EXTENDING EMPLOYMENT AND TRAINING OPPORTUNITIES FOR YOUTH.  THE APPROVED VERSION OF THE BILL CONTAINS THE TEXT OF S. 1242, THE SENATE COMPANION BILL TO THE ORIGINAL MEASURE.

TO AMEND S. 1523, A BILL AUTHORIZING APPROPRIATIONS FOR HOUSING AND COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT  ASSISTANCE PROGRAMS FOR FISCAL YEARS 1978 THROUGH 1980, BY REDUCING THE FUNDING FOR HOUSING ASSISTANCE TO $1.16 BILLION.
TO AMEND S. 1523 BY DELETING FROM THE BILL THE ENTIRE SECTION ON COMMUNITY REINVESTMENT.

TO AMEND S. 1523 WITH AMENDMENTS TO THE FEDERAL FLOOD INSURANCE ACT THAT PERMITS PROPERTY OWNERS THAT DID NOT ELECT TO PARTICIPATE IN THE HUD FLOOD INSURANCE PROGRAM TO STILL BE ELIGIBLE FOR OTHER FEDERALLY FUNDED LOANS SHOULD A FLOOD DISASTER OCCUR.
TO AMEND S. 1523 BY SUBSTITUTING THE PROPOSED FORMULA FOR ALLOCATION OF RURAL COMMUNITY  DEVELOPMENT GRANTS WITH THE FORMULA NOW IN USE.
TO AMEND S. 1523 BY ALLOWING THAT NOT ONLY COUNTIES AND CITIES BUT ALSO SEVERELY  DISTRESSED "AREAS" OF CITIES SHALL BE ELIGIBLE TO RECEIVE URBAN DEVELOPMENT ACTION GRANTS.
TO AMEND S. 1523 BY DELETING A SECTION THAT WOULD HAVE DISCONTINUED THE CONGRESSIONAL RIGHT TO ANALYZE THE IMPACT OF THE BILL ON FEDERAL SPENDING.
TO PASS H.R. 6655, THE HOUSING AND COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT ACT OF 1977, AFTER STRIKING ALL AFTER THE ENACTING CLAUSE AND INSERTING IN LIEU THEREOF THE TEXT OF S. 1523.

TO ALTER S. 252, PROPOSED CLEAN AIR ACT AMENDMENTS OF 1977, WITH AN AMENDMENT  TO THE HART AMENDMENT.  THE GRIFFIN-RIEGLE AMENDMENT ASKS FOR AN EPA STUDY ON THE HEALTH IMPLICATIONS, THE COST AND THE TECHNICAL FEASIBILITY OF A 0.4 NITROGEN OXIDE EMISSION STANDARD FOR LIGHT DUTY VEHICLES.

TO TABLE DIVISION I OF THE GRIFFIN AMENDMENT TO THE NELSON AMENDMENT (SEE RC 181)  TO S. 252.  DIVISION I OF THE GRIFFIN AMENDMENT SPECIFIES THAT ONLY AMERICAN MANUFACTURERS ARE ELIGIBLE FOR THE DEADLINE EXTENSION GIVEN TO SMALL BUSINESSES WITH RESPECT TO MEETING AIR QUALITY STANDARDS.

TO TABLE DIVISION II OF THE GRIFFIN AMENDMENT TO THE NELSON AMENDMENT (SEE RC 181)  TO S. 252.  DIVISION II OF THE GRIFFIN AMENDMENT EXTENDS FOR ONE YEAR THE DEADLINE FOR EMISSIONS LIMITATIONS THAT ARE REQUIRED FOR SMALL AMERICAN AUTO MANUFACTURERS.
TO AMEND S. 252 BY ALLOWING A TWO YEAR EXTENSION OF THE DEADLINE FOR COMPLIANCE  WITH EPA STANDARDS FOR ANY MANUFACTURER OF LESS THAN 300,000 CARS A YEAR.
TO AMEND S. 252 BY REQUIRING NATIONAL PARK LANDS SMALLER THAN 6,000 ACRES TO MEET CLASS I AIR QUALITY STANDARDS.

TO AMEND S. 252 WITH AN AMENDMENT TO THE GARN AMENDMENT #317, THE EFFECT OF WHICH  WOULD BE TO ALLOW THAT THE AIR QUALITY STANDARDS FOR CLASS I AND CLASS II AREAS BE EXCEEDED FOR UP TO 18 DAYS A YEAR.

TO AMEND S. 252 WITH A SUBSTITUTE FOR THE RIEGLE AMENDMENT (SEE RC 185) THAT WAIVES  FOR AN ADDITIONAL TWO YEARS THE HYDROCARBON AND CARBON MONOXIDE EMISSION STANDARDS FOR AUTO INDUSTRIES AND ESTABLISHES FINAL STANDARDS FOR 1980 AND BEYOND.
TO AMEND S. 252 BY SETTING A NEW SCHEDULE OF COMPLIANCE DEADLINES FOR AUTO MANUFACTURERS  REQUIRED TO MEET NEW EMISSION STANDARDS.
TO AMEND S. 252 BY ALLOWING THE INDIVIDUAL STATES AND COUNTIES TO SET THEIR OWN AIR QUALITY STANDARDS HIGHER THAN THE NATIONAL ONES SET BY THE EPA.
TO AMEND S. 252 BY AUTHORIZING THE PRESIDENT TO REQUIRE THE USE OF LOCAL COAL SUPPLIES IN ANY STATE OR COUNTY BEFORE ALLOWING THE USE OF IMPORTED COAL SUPPLIES.
TO TABLE THE RANDOLPH MOTION TO RECONSIDER THE METZENBAUM AMENDMENT TO S. 252.  (SEE  RC 187)

TO AGREE TO AN AMENDMENT OFFERED AS A SUBSTITUTE FOR THE HATCH AMENDMENT TO S. 252.   THE HART AMENDMENT RESTORES TO THE STATES THE RIGHT TO INSPECT, AT THE EXPENSE OF THE MANUFACTURER, THE EMISSIONS STANDARDS OF ANY CAR BEFORE ITS INITIAL RETAIL SALE, TITLING,  OR REGISTRATION.
TO PASS H.R. 6161, CLEAN AIR ACT AMENDMENTS OF 1977, AFTER STRIKING ALL AFTER THE  ENACTING CLAUSE AND SUBSTITUTING THEREFOR THE LANGUAGE OF S. 252.

TO TABLE THE MELCHER AMENDMENT TO S. 1340, THE BILL AUTHORIZING APPROPRIATIONS FOR  NONNUCLEAR PROGRAMS OF THE ENERGY RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT ADMINISTRATION FOR FISCAL YEAR 1978.  THE MELCHER AMENDMENT WOULD HAVE INCREASED THE APPROPRIATION FOR RESEARCH IN MAGNETOHYDRODYNAMICS TO $125 MILLION.
TO AMEND S. 1340 BY INCREASING TO $88 MILLION THE APPROPRIATION FOR RESEARCH IN  MAGNETOHYDRODYNAMICS.
TO AMEND S. 1340 BY REDUCING FROM 2,500 TO 200 THE NUMBER OF EXPERIMENTAL ELECTRIC  VEHICLES THAT ERDA MAY PURCHASE FOR THE PURPOSE OF DEMONSTRATING THE NEW ELECTRICAL TECHNOLOGY.
TO AMEND S. 1340 BY DELETING THE APPROPRIATION OF $28.3 MILLION FOR THE CONSTRUCTION  OF A COAL LIQUIFICATION PLANT IN BAYTOWN, TEXAS, TO BE OWNED BY THE EXXON CORPORATION.
TO PASS S. 1340.

TO AMEND H.R. 5262, THE BILL AUTHORIZING U.S. CONTRIBUTIONS TO SIX MAJOR INTERNATIONAL  FINANCIAL INSTITUTIONS, BY INSERTING A CLAUSE THAT RECOGNIZES THE NEED FOR U.S. COMMITMENT TO INTERNATIONAL FINANCIAL INSTITUTIONS AND THAT CLARIFIES THE FACT THAT U.S. CONTRIBUTIONS ARE SUBJECT TO THE APPROPRIATIONS PROCESS.

THE DOLE AMENDMENT STATES THE SENSE  OF THE CONGRESS THAT THERE SHOULD BE NO U.S. DIPLOMATIC RELATIONS WITH THE GOVERNMENT OF CUBA, NOR SHOULD THERE BE A PARTIAL OR COMPLETE LIFTING OF THE U.S. TRADE EMBARGO AGAINST CUBA UNTIL SUCH TIME AS CERTAIN ACTIONS ARE TAKEN BY THE CUBAN GOVERNMENT WITH REGARD TO HUMAN RIGHTS AND EXPROPRIATED LANDS.
TO TABLE THE BYRD,(D,WV) AMENDMENT (SEE RC 215) OFFERED AS A SUBSTITUTE FOR  THE DOLE AMENDMENT #468 (SEE RC 213) TO H.R. 6689.

THE BYRD AMENDMENT STATES THE SENSE OF THE CONGRESS THAT "ANY NEGOTIATIONS TOWARD THE NORMALIZATION OF RELATIONS WITH CUBA SHALL BE CONDUCTED IN A DELIBERATE MANNER AND ON A RECIPROCAL BASIS," AND THAT THE CONCERNS OF THE U.S. WITH REGARD TO CUBAN MILITARY AND HUMAN RIGHTS POLICIES SHALL BE TAKEN INTO STRONG ACCOUNT.
